Love the visual design. The looks and gameplay kinda remind me of old flash games in a good way. The movement of your character is fluid yet weighty, and the abilities make you feel powerful. Carrion es un título único en el que controlas a una criatura monstruosa y debes acabar con los humanos que se interponen en tu camino.
El juego sigue el esquema básico de los metroidvania, pero con un giro interesante: ¡aquí tú eres el monstruo!
A medida que avanzas en el juego, podrás desbloquear nuevas habilidades y evolucionar tu forma para enfrentarte a desafíos más difíciles.
Carrion destaca por su jugabilidad satisfactoria y su atmósfera oscura y perturbadora.
A través de sus niveles intrincados, deberás utilizar tus habilidades y astucia para superar obstáculos y derrotar a tus enemigos.
El juego ha sido bien recibido por los jugadores y ha obtenido críticas positivas por su originalidad y su enfoque fresco en el género de acción.
Si te gustan los juegos de acción desafiantes y disfrutas de la perspectiva de jugar como el villano, Carrion podría ser una excelente opción para ti.
En resumen, Carrion es un juego de acción en el que encarnas a una monstruosa masa de carne y debes enfrentarte a los humanos. Con su jugabilidad única y su atmósfera inquietante, ofrece una experiencia emocionante y diferente.

150642344.review:
[h1]Overall Impressions[/h1]
Reviewed after 100% completion. A surprisingly fun puzzler, wrapped in an atmospheric package. 

[h1]What I Liked[/h1]
The atmosphere in this game is really great. You feel like a menacing "THING" like entity that can devour anything in it's patch. It feels really great to naturally gain new abilities over the course of the story that also unlock new areas. this is nothing new for metroid-vania style games, but it was well done here. 

Movement and combat are physics based, and rather fun to experiment with. Bursting through a vent and hurling enemies at each other never got old. 

[h1]What Could Be Improved[/h1]
The game is fairly short, which some may see as a negative. However, with all the 80+ hour games in recent memory, I found it rather refreshing to have a self contained playable experience that is short but doesn't compromise on content. 

I did find a few instances where I needed to reload in order to "unstick" myself from certain puzzles. I'm not sure if this was required, or if I just could not think of any other solutions. Thankfully these instances were really rare. 

[h1]Final Thoughts & Rating[/h1]
A standout entry in the slew of recent metroid-vania style games. This one offers a fresh take on the player character, and the puzzles felt very satisfying. This game felt like a refined package, and is highly recommended if you are into this genre or monsters.

[h2]★★★★☆[/h2]

Would give it a side-way thumb if Steam had such option. Overall an alright game. You get to play as a brutal monster, you get to eat people and that is where most fun will be. 

Sadly, it is also attached to unnecessary amounts of backtracking (should have been just a linear story) and tons of dead air resulting from said backtracking. 

Powers are fun but a bit oddly designed. Let's say there is Obstacle-A that needs you to be your level 1 form. If you happen to be level 2 (basically eat 2-3 people), you cannot solve that obstacle. Later, you get a long range tentacle for possessing people. That thing can go through the same gaps as the level 1-ability, yet sadly the game says "no". So what you have to do is to go to some red water and "drop biomass" to be level 1 again, solely for the purpose of turning a lever.

This, creates a lot of dead air. Really a lot. Killing the main fun, or rather, only fun the game has: Attacking people and eating them.

149913393.review:
Carrion is an excellent, short, reverse-horror experience with perfect tone and fun gameplay.

The art style, soundtrack, and sound design all work well together to deliver a sufficiently creepy, yet pleasing aesthetic. The gameplay feels smooth and unique. The way the monster moves throughout the levels is immediately satisfying, mostly due to the fantastic tentacle animations. 

The level design is alright. There are some cool rooms with interesting combat encounters, though I think the levels could use a few more non-combat puzzles with more depth than "acquire ability to pass this barrier".

My one complaint is that there are some combat encounters that feel a bit cheap in that they lock you into a room with a difficulty spike with no warning, pretty much setting you up for failure. Luckily, the save system is fairly generous, so you don't have to back-track too much. 

Overall, I loved this game and my one regret it letting it sit in my library so long before giving in a whirl.

149823288.review: Overall a decent game with an innovative concept. Yes, the price is surely too high for what you get in return, wait for a heavy discount. Although I rarely enjoy forced stealth, this one was pleasantly executed. Even threw some puzzles at you in between the slaughter. It does get a tad bit repetitive despite your arsenal growing throughout the game. Maybe a bit more variety in playstyle could have improved that. But in the game's defense, it's pretty short anyway. And yes, that's sort of what makes the price unjustified. I think my biggest problem is the navigation, however. It's easy to get lost or wander an unintended path. This is the sort of game that would have greatly benefited from a map. Or at the very least some form of fast travel between the areas so I'm not stuck searching for a needle in a haystack. I understand that this is a creative choice to convey that you're a fish out of water and have nobody holding your hand, but some kind of upgrade to assist the navigation sure would have been nice. The only feature that partially aids you in finding points of interest is rather obsolete as you would have to pass those areas anyway to proceed. This game certainly has a lot of untouched potential.

149439716.review:
TL;DR: despite some stupid gameplay decisions, still would recommend to get this game on a sale.

Honestly, i'm not even sure what did i expect from this game.

There are a lot of frustrating gameplay decisions made by devs, that's for sure.
While it can be a positive for some, but for me the experience was underwhelming because of that.

For example, lack of a map in a game like this is disastrous, you have to traverse these literal mazes and try to make your way to the end, and then try to get back to certain sections to get the upgrade which you couldn't get because you were missing some ability. It's awful, i had to look for a steam guide to check the layouts of those 10 locations because there is a main "hub" from which you can get to every other location, but it is impossible to guess whether the location is main hub or not, you just have to spend some time rolling around trying to get to the next chapter for you to lose patience and go look for player-created map layouts.
The game felt super claustrophobic, but not because of narrow tunnels, but due to how close to the action the camera was positioned. This is probably because some locations are tiny and it wouldn't make sense to pull the camera out, but still i'd love to be able to zoom out at least a little bit. Sometimes it felt like i was watching close-up documentary about alien lifeforms.

On the other hand, Carrion is pretty challenging but enemy encounters feel fair.
The puzzles were interesting and made me use my brain, so that's a plus.
Getting new abilities is interesting and i was always looking forward to what i was going to get next.
It took me almost 5 hours to 100% the game, which is decent, since the game didn't get too stale in such a short amount of time.
Also, the achievements made sense and there was no bs. Get stuff - get your achievement, no need to grind for arbitrary amount of "points", kills or some other dumb shit.

149397618.review:
What an absolute blast! 

If you've ever fantasized about wreaking havoc as a horrifying monster, this game is your dream come true.

The gameplay mechanics are intuitive, and the control you have is incredibly empowering. The fluidity of movement, the visceral attacks, and the ability to traverse the environment with eerie grace make for an immersive experience that keeps you hooked from start to finish.

The level design is brilliant, offering a perfect balance of challenging puzzles and satisfyingly gruesome combat scenarios. The way the environment reacts to your monstrous presence is a testament to the attention to detail put into the game. It's not just about mindless destruction; there's a certain strategy involved in navigating the world and overcoming obstacles.

My only gripe is that the game doesn't include a map, as it can be quite chaotic to backtrack if you want to get a 100% completion.  It's not a dealbreaker, but it does test your spatial awareness and memory.

The game has left me hungry for more.

149125690.review:
[h1] Consume and adapt [/h1]

[b] Gameplay [/b]
You play as an alien that consumes everything in its path and will stop at nothing. The game is linear having you go from point A to point B but you will receive traits that will aid you on your journey. There are some missable secrets in each level called Containment Units. [spoiler] There is no map [/spoiler]

[b] Story [/b]
The story is told from your perspective and begins with you breaking free of your containment tube and escaping into a massive facility. The game makes it clear from the start that you want out. The game periodically switches to the perspective of a researcher, but it wasn't clear what information conveyed or when those events took place.

[b] Music [/b]
Extremely fitting for what's happening at the time, nothing out of the ordinary but it amplifies the feeling of being the bad guy.

Conclusion.
If you are a fan of John Carpenter's The Thing (1982), I suggest you really try it out, you might find some similarities. If you're not a fan, try it anyway; it's a hidden gem.

149096976.review: There's potential in Carrion, but as it stands it's mostly just a flash game. The graphic design is not very good, and the game isn't much fun to play. Just by the premise, it sounds like it would be really interesting, but there isn't any true reward to your time and money invested. It's an insanely short game with no real replayability. The controls and mechanics are obnoxious, trying to force in puzzles and power-ups in a way that feels entirely artificial. Though there's entertaining sounds and some vaguely challenging segments, it never becomes really amusing to play. You're at your weakest at the start and it's insanely disappointing, but by the end of the game it just feels tedious. There's only a few small parts where I felt it genuinely played on the amorphous tentacled monster trope, but I think there's just something that is not satisfying about how it's played. Get it on sale, or skip it entirely.

149091359.review:
[h1] Overview [/h1]

[b] FULL DISCLOSURE: I PURCHASED THIS ON SALE [/b]

The game was short but it was POTENT and I don't regret my purchase at all! I thought I might have trouble with the puzzles but it was all very intuitive to me. I'm sure thousands have said this already but a sequel would be incredible, it doesn't even have to be the same style of game.

Oh, and my computer is bottom of the barrel dirt garbage and the game had zero performance issues even when there was a lot happening on screen, so don't worry too much about having performance issues.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
You [i] can [/i] get lost but following your gut instinct will usually lead you where you need to go.  I also really liked how you can approach problems and areas creatively, you can go in and rampage through a room, or you can be insidious and terrorize the helpless workers until you get bored. Maybe there's something wrong with me but cornering somebody and letting them live after I just ripped their co-workers head off just fills me with glee, like yeah lil guy go home and tell your family what you witnessed, tell the world the terror you've experienced.

[h2] A Very Small Critique [/h2]

Honestly the only part of the game I had issues with was [spoiler] the first human portion of the game where you're supposed to plant C4 on the wall but it isn't very clearly communicated at all that you're supposed to do that [/spoiler] which consumed a good 10 minutes of my time. 

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

I would love to see this turn into a large franchise, it really ticks all the boxes for me. I'd give the game a [b] 9.5/10 [/b] which sounds exaggerated but this is a genre we never really see and I really had a smile on my face the whole playthrough. A real gem in my Steam Library.

Good but not worth the full price:

Whilst I very much like the gameplay and the 2d art design (especially the monster), the core gameplay here is very shallow. I played for around 30 minutes and found there was not much more to the game. Just look at people's few hours into this game and ask yourself whether you'd pay that much. Minimal skills to unlock, no real evolution of the monster (mainly aesthetic), limited enemy types, barebones story (see the Alien story from AVP as a good example), and no customisation of the monster. Also, each *room* is separated by a brief fade to black loading screen - surely this is unnecessary?

If this was in early access and cheaper, I'd say buy it. However, this game lacks content to justify the price. Feels very early access or a free website game. Concept is still very strong and would be interested in a sequel with content and story.

148483309.review:
Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Carrion, a unique and unsettling reverse-horror game, is a captivating experience that had me immersed in its nightmarish world for 3.5 hours. It's a game that takes the traditional concept of being the hero and flips it on its head, allowing you to become the lurking monstrosity.

Carrion casts you in the role of an amorphous, tentacled creature that escapes from a containment facility. Your primary objective is to wreak havoc, consume everything in your path, and navigate the maze-like environment to unveil the secrets behind your existence.

One of Carrion's most intriguing aspects is its gameplay. As the nameless monster, you are a force of destruction and chaos. Your abilities include slashing through obstacles, latching onto humans to devour them, and regenerating health by consuming biomass. This unique approach to gameplay provides a refreshing change of perspective from traditional horror games, where you are usually the prey.

The level design in Carrion is praiseworthy. Each area offers a series of puzzles, challenges, and enemies, making it feel like a living and breathing ecosystem that you, as the monster, must adapt to. Progressing through the game involves using your evolving abilities strategically to bypass obstacles and defeat adversaries.

Carrion's atmospheric design also deserves recognition. The pixel-art visuals are both gruesome and beautiful, capturing the grotesque nature of the creature and the dark, eerie environment in which it thrives. The sound design further amplifies the tension, with eerie noises and cries of terrified humans, adding to the sense of horror and immersion.

However, the game's brevity is one of its main downsides. At 3.5 hours of gameplay, Carrion is a relatively short experience, leaving you craving more of its unique and terrifying world. The narrative is minimal, with the story mostly conveyed through environmental storytelling and notes found throughout the game, which can leave you wanting more depth in the plot.

Carrion is undoubtedly an unconventional and memorable horror experience that flips the genre's conventions on their head. As the player, you get to embrace the role of the predator and become the embodiment of terror. Although it's a bit on the shorter side, the game's gripping gameplay, atmospheric design, and inventive premise make it a must-play for horror enthusiasts looking for something refreshingly different.

148005937.review:
[u][b]In Short[/b][/u]
I won this game in a giveaway and I'm glad I finally gave it chance after so long. I wasn't sure if I would like a reverse horror game, but I may've had too much fun playing it... +1 perfect games!

[hr][/hr]
[u][b]Detailed Version[/b][/u]
I've enjoyed some 2D games here and there, but I've never gone out of my way to seek one. After playing this though, I might be swayed... I don't know if it was the reverse horror sub-genre or the satisfaction of swinging people around so fluidly, but it was kind of a vibe!

[i][u]Story[/u][/i]
It seems Carrion was more of an introduction to the "amorphous creature of unknown origin" as any remnants of a story reside in the various flashbacks you encounter along your path of carnage. In the end, not much information is given on the creature other than it being hungry. I haven't looked much into it, but it seems there're hints of a sequel. I hope so! I could see writers taking what was given to us already and spinning quite a story out of it for the next game.

[i][u]Movement[/u][/i]
I found the controls pretty clunky. It defaults to controller, but it made more sense to play on MKB for me. Even near the end, I found myself getting a bit jumbled here and there. I really wish they would've allowed for WASD movement instead of just the mouse. On a similar note... No map. Period. I get why though! I say more later, but it would make the game far too easy.

[i][u]Combat[/u][/i]
This is where the game really shines. Grabbing and munching down on people, grabbing and throwing people, throwing objects at people... There're just so many ways to get the job done. That doesn't even take into consideration the best part of this game...

[i][u]Abilities[/u][/i]
There are quite a few. I won't say how much, but I'll say that the creature ends up with 3 varying sizes. These sizes grant the option of using certain abilities, if unlocked. This added a bit of a puzzle aspect to the game, which was unexpected, but I absolutely loved it.
 
[u][b]For 100%ers[/b][/u]
The biggest obstacle is the map. Or rather... the lack thereof. I urge you to try your best before using this, but you do you! Below is a link to the maps from the official wiki. I ended up using them after failing to navigate the world for probably an hour...

[b][url=https://carrion.fandom.com/wiki/Special:AllMaps]Interactive Maps[/url][/b] on Carrion Wiki

[u]Please thumbs up. I'd greatly appreciate it![/u]

A lack of a map and frequent one-way transit tubes combine to make the worst metroidvania experience I've ever had.

I'm not saying there aren't any worse ones out there, but this was very little fun for an immense amount of frustration.

Is it cool to be an amorphous flesh monster? Absolutely, but that isn't all that the game is about. Beyond the nonexistent map, which is just absurd and offensive, the controls can be janky as well, especially when you unlock the bigger forms of your monster. If I'm struggling to make my shambling biohorror go the correct way, maybe the controls should've been tightened up before release? 

Likewise, on the different sizes, I think I see what was attempted by giving each size different abilities for combat and path opening, but in practice it was just an unclear, unengaging mess of almost gameplay. Neat ideas, sure, but forced in rather than worked in.

All told, it really is a neat concept, but that isn't enough to carry disgustingly frustrating gameplay. This won't scratch that exploration itch if that is want you're after. Meanwhile, if all you want is to kill people as a flowing shapeless flesh tide, well the trailers and let's plays don't really show you the tedium and annoyance of the rest of the game.

147245072.review:
Really really wish Steam had a "neutral" option. I beat the game in 4 hours, including all the secret finds. I did get this on sale, and for 5 bucks, that's reasonable; however, for a full 20, I can't recommend the game. 

Done well:
-The aesthetic of the game is excellent. The monster looks and sounds creepy and the game world complements it well. The screams of terrified scientists are a fun incentive to tear them apart mercilessly.
-The game blends puzzles and combat very well; MOST of your combat tools can be used for puzzles, all the puzzle tools can be used for combat.
-The puzzles themselves are well designed; none of them were particularly difficult, but some did require some thinking. They are mostly obvious through trial and error, with a couple big exceptions due to a point of game design.
Done poorly:
-Nitpick, but the energy-using upgrade for the mid-stage form I used exactly once when I got it and never again, since it's only applicable in combat and you have much better options.
-The puzzles that involve the explosive clamp spears are very annoying, since the clamp-spears instakill you, instead of simply blocking your progress like a door or lever. That's the puzzle disappointment I mentioned earlier.
-The control scheme relying so heavily on the left mouse button meant I had to play the game in short stints, since holding it down for too long became painful. 
-The lack of a map or a central hub area made backtracking for the secrets tedious. There is a central area from which you can see the status of every level, but you actually have to find the level gates to get back there, and the monitors don't indicate their positions at all.
-The echolocation ability that lets you find nests is worthless, since active nests (where you've been) and inactive nests (where you haven't) appear the same, and there's an upgrade that further clutters the ability with a response from edible corpses.
-The ending was rather abrupt and disappointing. INSIDE this is not.

In short: wait for a sale, enjoy it for what it is. I feel like the concept could have gone much further than it did.

[h1]Delightfully Anti-Human[/h1]

While the full work does not exceed the trappings of what amounts to a high quality flash game that you might have found in an early 2000's browser, the natural quality of the work shines beyond all.
The experience is short, but is a fast paced roller coaster that straps you in and rockets you into a new world.
Movement is fluid, powers are easily understood, the art is visceral and beautiful - there's so much to like.
Once you start the game, there's little to feather the breaks as you tumble through the disgusting and monstrous piece.

At its heart, Carrion is a puzzle game, where problem solving and a little bit of ingenuity is what paves the way forward. And in this, it is a wonderful bit of art. The levels are stimulating enough to escape the ocean of monotonous puzzle titles, but is not overbearing or perplexing to the point of squelching the ambitions of the casual players.

It simply provides a well rounded story, good game-play, tight level design, and a highly unique premise.

There ought to be an entire genre out there revolving around playing as monsters and other non-humans, because this is an ace performance by every name on the credit roll.

~
8/10

It starts with an explosion and does its very best to keep the momentum, and ends with a satisfying payoff.
There should be more games like this out there.

It's a game where you are the evil monster which tries to escape from a facility.

Oh boyyy do I love being evil, it's really satisfying crawling behind walls, under floors or above the soldier's heads in the ceiling... But I love scaring them to death, in a quite literal way. You really feel that everyone is terrified when you suddenly show up.
And that's what I like too : you can choose to sneak up discreetly or try to rush them brutally, and both methods work great! There are also a few puzzles that are not very hard but use the various mechanics in great ways.

The game is very linear, I didn't find it to be a problem but you may find it annoying (maybe). However, after completing the last area, you can feel kinda lost because of something I both like and dislike : there's no map. As an Evil Creature you can't access a map, it's immersive, but adding a wall map per area could have made exploration better... Or not. It's a small world after all so it's not that hard to navigate (however I admit that I used some community-made maps for 100%).

Great feelings, great game, 6 hours to finish (short :/) and a bit more for 100% and/or completing the included "Christmas DLC" map.

145282155.review:
Carrion is atmospheric and immersive metroidvania-lite with unique twist - it's "reverse horror".

While Carrion with it's expansive interconnected map and unlockable shortcuts can be classified as metroidvania, it tries it's hardest, not to make you feel lost or backtrack at all. This is thanks to impressive level design that creates a sense of complexity while maintaining an unbroken flow from one area to another, with no interruption, and no slowdown, keeping you fully immersed at all times.

This seamless 'flow' contributes to the game's shorter duration (5-6 hours) and relatively low difficulty. Yet this aligns perfectly with core theme of the game. You assume the role of a unstoppable biological contagion, reminiscent of sci-fi horrors like Alien, The Thing, and Life. The game's length and difficulty mirror the nature of your character as an unstoppable force, delivering a reverse horror experience that masterfully nails homage to its inspirations.

From a technical standpoint, the graphics are simple yet solid with "meaty" feeling that complements the game's overall vibe. Music and sound design are good, further contributing to the immersion, and I'm almost sure I could occasionally hear familiar cues from Alien. Controls might require bit of getting used to, but ultimately don't hinder the experience.

I wholeheartedly recommend Carrion. It serves as an excellent palate cleanser between longer, more involved games.

145105574.review:
Title: A Bloodcurdling Masterpiece - My Review of "Carrion"

"Carrion" is an indie gem that thrusts players into a spine-chilling, asymmetrical horror experience unlike any other. Developed by Phobia Game Studio and published by Devolver Digital, this game takes a bold leap into the unconventional, allowing players to become the nightmare itself. As you delve into the dark depths of this reverse-horror title, prepare to be both thrilled and horrified in a way that only "Carrion" can deliver.

Set in a sprawling underground research facility, "Carrion" places you in the role of an amorphous, tentacled monstrosity with a single aim: to escape and unleash chaos upon the unsuspecting world above. What immediately sets "Carrion" apart is its reverse-perspective, turning the traditional survival horror genre on its head. No longer are you the prey, cowering in fear of lurking terrors – you are the predator, a relentless force of nature that grows stronger with each passing moment.

The pixel art aesthetics of "Carrion" deserve a special mention. Despite its retro-inspired visuals, the game manages to create an incredibly eerie atmosphere, dripping with tension. The labyrinthine corridors, dimly lit rooms, and gory carnage are all brought to life with an impressive attention to detail. The animation of the titular creature is a highlight, as it squelches, stretches, and unfurls its gruesome form to navigate the environment in a truly unsettling manner.

The game-play in "Carrion" revolves around mastering your unique abilities. From the start, you'll feel both powerful and vulnerable as you gradually gain access to an arsenal of gruesome tools. Your amorphous being can slink through vents, squeeze through tight spaces, and lash out with deadly tentacles to snare and devour your human prey. The controls, while a bit unconventional at first, quickly become second nature, allowing you to execute gruesome kills with precision.

The level design is a mixed bag, offering a combination of intricate puzzles and intense chase sequences. While some areas encourage methodical exploration, others push you to use your agility and cunning to evade armed guards and security systems. The puzzles are generally well-designed, requiring a balance of strategic thinking and experimentation. However, there are instances where trial and error can feel frustrating, disrupting the overall flow.

One of "Carrion's" minor flaws lies in its lack of a compelling narrative. While the premise is intriguing and the game's minimalist storytelling approach aligns with its retro sensibilities, a stronger narrative thread could have heightened player investment and motivation. That being said, the absence of an intricate plot doesn't detract significantly from the overall experience, as the game-play itself remains the central attraction.

"Carrion" also boasts a hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack that complements the game-play perfectly. The eerie ambient sounds and subtle musical cues enhance the tension and contribute to the overall feeling of dread as you navigate the claustrophobic corridors.

All in all, "Carrion" is an electrifying journey into the unconventional, offering a fresh twist on the horror genre that fans of unique gaming experiences will relish. It's a testament to the creative potential of indie game development, delivering an immersive world, captivating mechanics, and a truly unforgettable role reversal. While a stronger narrative and some refining of level design could have elevated it even further, "Carrion" undeniably stands as a remarkable and nightmarishly fun title that dares to be different. If you're ready to unleash your inner monster and revel in a macabre adventure, "Carrion" should absolutely be on your radar.

TLDR: Carrion: A unique platformer where you play as a tentacle monster. Interesting and fun, but its short campaign makes it a better buy on sale.

Gather 'round, fans of the twisted and unique! 'Carrion' invites you to step into the slimy shoes (or tentacles) of a monstrous blob. In a brief but engaging 6-hour playthrough, you'll puzzle-solve and people-absorb your way through a world filled with intrigue. While the graphics and sound design hit the mark, the story might leave you with a lingering hunger for more answers.

Despite its fascinating concept and enjoyable gameplay, 'Carrion' might feel a bit too short for its full price tag. So, if you're eager to explore what it's like to be the nightmare creature in a horror flick, you might want to snag this game during a sale.

143744784.review:
Carrion, developed by Phobia Game Studio, is a uniquely thrilling and engrossing video game that offers players a refreshing take on the horror genre. In this game, players find themselves in the role of an amorphous and malevolent creature, an abomination escaping from a research facility. The game's innovative premise and mechanics create a truly captivating experience, but at times, it can be hindered by elements that introduce moments of tedium.

One of the most exhilarating aspects of Carrion is the ability to control a creature that embodies pure chaos and destruction. The creature's lack of defined shape and the way it elegantly traverses the environment, using its tentacles to cling to surfaces, deliver a sense of empowerment that few games can match. This power fantasy is the foundation of Carrion's enjoyment, as players revel in unleashing havoc upon the terrified humans who cross their path. The unorthodox approach to the horror genre makes Carrion stand out, offering a fresh perspective from the typical protagonist-versus-monster formula.

The game's puzzles and challenges contribute to its excitement, as players must solve intricate tasks using the creature's unique abilities. Employing stealth, strategy, and brute force, players must outsmart armed human adversaries and navigate through tight spaces, all while devouring hapless victims to grow stronger. These engaging gameplay elements make for a rollercoaster ride of adrenaline-pumping moments, culminating in a satisfyingly satisfying experience.

However, amidst the excitement, Carrion does suffer from occasional bouts of tedium. Some sections of the game can feel repetitive, with players having to backtrack through areas they've previously explored. This repetition can dampen the otherwise intense pace and sense of progression. Additionally, the lack of a clear map or objective markers can lead to moments of aimless wandering, which might frustrate players seeking a more streamlined experience.

Furthermore, the game's narrative is deliberately minimalistic, leaving players to piece together the story through environmental clues and scattered notes. While this storytelling approach can be intriguing for some, it may leave others wanting a more well-defined plot. The absence of a deeper emotional connection to the creature's motivations and background might hinder some players' investment in the game's overall narrative.

Despite these drawbacks, Carrion remains an exceptional and memorable experience, especially for players seeking something different from the usual horror-themed games. Its gripping gameplay, innovative concept, and darkly atmospheric setting provide a refreshing take on the genre. The moments of tedium can be overlooked in light of the overall thrill and enjoyment the game offers.

In conclusion, Carrion is a game that takes risks and successfully ventures beyond conventional gaming norms. It is fun, exciting, and leaves a lasting impression on players with its unique premise and gameplay. However, the occasional tedium and lack of a robust narrative might not appeal to everyone. Nonetheless, Carrion stands as a testament to the potential for ingenuity within the horror genre and should be experienced by anyone seeking a fresh and visceral gaming experience.

8/10

143636824.review:
Overall: 7.8/10

Pros:
- Very fun premise
- Atmospheric and immersive
- Fun/pleasing  movement

Cons:
- No quest tracker or map system, making it easy to get lost or confused
- Low enemy diversity
- Incomplete campaign  experience  in my opinion- they have moments where you play flashbacks of scientists, but the game ends (or CAN end) without explaining/resolving the origins  of you,  as a monster. Seems sloppy to me.
- No final  kind of boss fight, they just chuck more populated puzzle rooms at you.
- The puzzles  can get kind of repetitive as they crutch on the same mechanics most of the time.
- All game achievements are hidden.

All in all, this  is a game that could have  been  MUCH better if they had a better take on Metroidvania style games. There are  multiple realities in  the game that don't  really make sense-

1) You often  run into barriers that you cannot move through, even though you're a conglomeration of writhing worms and tendrils. This makes sense in some senses- like a fully impermeable plane like strong plexiglass or something like that. But there's a specific block that  is pretty much just  4 stone pillars, that serve as a bodyblock,  while allowing you to shoot webs through. HOWEVER,  if you are submerged in water, you can dissemble into a colony  of worms and slither past them... what? Why? Who thought this was a good or reasonable idea? If this thing can squeeze into vents, it can slide around some pillars.

2) You have exclusive abilities tied to your size, which is tied to your health. While this makes sense in some cases, it doesn't  make sense in most others- you can shoot  web in your smallest form, but somehow lose that  capability by getting bigger? What? One of the upgrades you get isn't even  useful, which feels underwhelming and frustrating. (Spike armor) This game would have had much more interesting possibilities if you were able to use all abilities at all sizes, but made physical size correlate  to another aspect of tile puzzles, like some vents  or pipes require smallest form, and some gaps requiring maximum size  to  cross. It feels like a lack of thought.

3) Non-required game upgrades are underwhelming- just health and energy buffs, or additional  tendrils (doesn't really change anything, compared to something like increasing tendril range, which would be VERY beneficial)

4) The ending  is quite lackluster in  my  opinion. It could have been  fixed if they let you actually rampage or something... but with the lack of a final bossfight, it feels...  empty.


TLDR: Enjoy the game on sale, or perhaps delve into modding it into what you hope it could be. I'd be very hopeful if they remade this game, or launched a sequel.

7.5/10 (Pretty Good!)

Pros: This is a game where you play as a lovecraftian flesh entity, and you go on a rampage on those who imprisoned you.  You have a great feeling of power and satisfaction whenever you make progress.  The game has a nice pixel style kind of like rain world or old retro games, going well with the side-scroller gameplay.

Cons: THE MAP IS A FREAKING MAZE SOMETIMES.  The game doesn't always do the best job telling you where to go and how to do it.  I've spent an hour alone just looping back and forth trying to find where to go.
The game could REALLY use some sort of mini map system.  This might sound like a skill issue on my part, but if you play it you'll know what I mean after 30 min,.

Over all this game is an acquired taste.  If you like games where you are the antagonist and/or a monster, and if you're ok with navigating a map that would put the randomness of The Backrooms to shame then try this game out!  If the aforementioned is not your cup of tea, then don't bother.

Over all 7.5/10 \\ I'd recommend .

142770291.review:
A fun reverse horror experience. Getting to play as the monster and going on a metroidvania adventure to collect alien DNA and evolve new nightmarish abilities - absolute recipe for success.

The game lives up to its premise as you crawl your way around the walls of each level, slowly expand your biomass by consuming scientists and civilians, learning to navigate by the sewers and vents in order to evade defences and use your many tendrils to grab, slam, throw, and consume your mortal prey. 

It's a fun ride with some interesting puzzles along the way, but there is very little variation in enemies and as much fun as it is to terrorise the humans it can get repetitive fast. The upgrades you get are mostly just functionality upgrades like extra energy, larger size, more strength, while the few more 'monstrous' abilities you gain end up being very circumstantial and directly get used to bypass literal progress gates.

The art style is great, very detailed for the pixelated look it goes with, but the music is pretty forgettable atmospheric horror stock. It gets points for uniqueness and ingenuity but there's a much better game that's been narrowly missed and that's disappointing to see. A good proof of concept, here's hoping they expand on what's been established in a more extensive follow up.

cons:

meh:

142384569.review:
If you like flesh monsters, tentacles, and devouring multiple people in rapid succession, this games hits those marks. 

I really enjoyed this game! I actually played it twice, and messed around with some workshop content. The story is quite basic, but there is some mystery to be had there. 

So, first things first. This game is actually quite easy. If you understand the movement most combat sections are quite simple, and in some cases even avoidable. The hardest enemy is a tiny drone and flamethrower soldier, that's it. Everything else is quite easy to navigate around so long you play with a little bit of skill. 

There are some aspects similar to metroidvanias, but excluding a few extra power-ups, the game is quite linear. That being said, the game is really easy to platinum. All but two achievements can be gained during the main game. The other two just require some hunting and backtracking. 

I really wish there was more! It is quite short, but for the amount of game that's there it's well worth it in my opinion. 

My only real complaint for this game is that the main "trail" is entirely too easy. I love it when games utilize their intelligent mechanics for solving puzzles, and while there is some of that, there's a few upgrade challenges that really highlight what could've been done.

142050614.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[b]This review is based on playing on the Steam deck.[/b]
[b]Carrion[/b] is a 2D side-viewed "reverse horror" experience in which you take control of an amorphous creature of unknown origins. With a killer art style that immerses the player and a unique gameplay mechanic of stalking your prey and consuming them for biomass, Carrion seems to be setting itself apart from the rest. But does it have enough biomass to escape the cell of indie monotony, or did it get eradicated before it even knew life?

Find out below

[table]
[tr]
	[th][b]🟩 Positives[/b][/th]
	[th][b]🟥 Negatives[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]🟩 Fun and innovative gameplay loop that helps set a new bar for the genre.

🟩 Well-designed map layout that allows each biome to remain outstanding but familiar. It also allows each encounter with the human forces to be mechanically unique and rewarding with a multi-path approach to any situation.

🟩 Visually stunning art style that perfectly conveys brutality and pain, as well as simplistic beauty and longing to escape.

🟩 The general audio and soundtrack are both impressive feats. Atmospheric and environmental effects sound natural and effective, while the subtle flow of the soundtrack tells its own story.[/td]

	[td]🟥 There is little to no narrated plot. Everything within the game merely occurs with remarkably little explanation.

🟥 Extremely short gameplay time.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The red, amorphic organism you control in the game remains unnamed for the entirety of [b]Carrion[/b]. You take control of it as the creature awakens from hibernation within a Seattle-based research company called Relith Science. After breaking free from its containment unit, the monster has to fight through the facility staff and security, consuming them for biomass as it seeks a means of escape. Along its journey to freedom, it discovers surgically removed pieces of its genetic code, and upon reinstituting these into itself, the creature can evolve, allowing for greater size and more means to both offence and defence as the security heightens the closer it gets to escape.

As I mentioned above, there isn't a lot of narrative to this title, where much of the game is left to you to decide what has happened and why this is happening. You get small snippets of information through flashback cutscenes you unlock through progression, but they are very short and don't convey much more than how you got to this facility. I didn't find this method of story-telling necessarily bad, it just leaves you guessing a lot of the time, and I feel the developers missed an opportunity to implement an unlock lore and story through consumption mechanic.

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[h3]Would you like parmesan cheese with your brutal carnage, sir?[/h3]
🟩 The creature is not a being of grace. It is primal wrath and chaos unfurling within the walls of the research facility, to everyone's great dismay. [b]Carrion[/b] does an exceptional job conveying this by allowing you to tactically stalk your prey and rip them to pieces within its brutal control mechanics.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3004088940

🟩 Combat is visceral as the creature tears through the facility without reservation, and avoiding both gunfire and actual fire will be crucial to survival. And with every cleared room, the chaos you have wreaked will be evident through the blood and entrail-stained walls depicting the tale of your eventual escape.

Without the pieces of your former self, you can't adequately evolve, and devouring enemies without these merely allows you to recover health and recover size back to your current cap.

🟩 You progress and save the game by depositing samples of your biomass into cracks and fissures located across the facility grounds.The newly formed hive is used to rip open seals between biomes, destroy large pieces of walls and many other things over the course of the story including saving your progress and healing you back to full.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3004088857

[h3]A different type of hide and seek.[/h3]
🟩 You rarely have size and power to your advantage, and you are, for a majority of the experience, poorly equipped to take on groups of or singularly powerful enemies without a plan in place. You will have to use your speed and timing to exact your revenge, and this often means hiding in air ducts and sewer systems, waiting for the perfect moment to strike and consume.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3004089203

🟩 Using your evolutionary abilities will help you greatly in the grand scheme, with each size variant of the creature having a different set of unique capabilities and talents that allow it to traverse the expansive confines of the facility and protect itself from the growing deluge of destruction that has been ordered to standing in its way.

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
[b]Carrion[/b] is a beautiful game that employs pixel-style graphics to depict a realistic and intensely graphic situation where a creature has escaped captivity. Blood-splattered rooms and devouring people is still a startling aspect of the title, but it somehow dulled thanks to the style, which wants you to focus on the experience of trying to escape more than the horror of the situation.

The audio is also astounding. All your movements as the creature sound as true-to-life as my imagination can dictate, facility workers screaming in terror at the sight of tendrils flying towards them, the splash of water as you dive into it to escape, all provide excellent atmosphere and immersion as you play, all of this coupled with a near flawless soundtrack and this is one hell of an experience.

[h1]Deck Performance and Specifications[/h1]
This title is the perfect game to play on the deck. The controls are responsive and clean, and the resolution is excellent for the graphical style.

There were no major or minor graphical issues to report.

[h1]Final Thoughts - Excellent[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
Falling short in only a couple of minor areas, [b]Carrion[/b] succeeds at creating an incredibly entertaining experience that takes you to the other side of a facility breach but also delivers an emotional journey as you witness the struggle to survive on both sides and the longing to be free. Despite its short length and lack of sufficient plot, I firmly believe this game is worth its current price point, but if you can get it on sale, even better!

[quote] Hunt, stalk and consume all you can, but when you finally achieve your freedom, head over to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43064204/] Hell, Purgatory and Paradise[/url] to truly get your fill.[/quote]

141683053.review:
[i]---see where this game landed on my Metroidvania tier list beneath this review!---[/i]


As a gaming creation, this is S tier.  
As a metroidvania:  D tier.  
My overall enjoyment: C tier.

I would rather call this 'metroidvania-like'.  I consider a big part of the metroidvania experience to be the mapping, which isn't present in Carrion.

While not really a puzzle game, the whole thing feels puzzly, which isn't really my style.  I found it best to play this game in small doses.  

The concept and execution really is brilliant though, it's a fantastic creation and an experience worth having, I respect, adore and appreciate what they've made here.

It's very short.  Grab it on sale if you think the concept looks cool.  ..Because it is.

141456037.review:
Sublime and cathartic.
The butter-smooth movement and progression flow so well that it's easy to continue on and peek into the next room.
Whether you're ripping doors off frames, batting someone with a computer, or knocking a silly human into deep water, you have a number of options for stopping them from shooting you. These increase as you unlock new abilities. If you like you can leave a pair of legs in the room in case you pass through later wanting a snack. As alluded to, it's delightful to discover how many things in the environment you can play with, like breaking lightbulbs and picking up rusted rail-carts.
As you acquire more abilities, as well as opening up new areas to explore, it gives you more tools to consider how to tackle humans. As they equip themselves with measures to counter grab-and-nom, the game takes on a puzzle aspect. Do you rely on your powers at a smaller biomass to protect your smaller healthbar, or take it more up close and personal with a higher biomass better able to soak up damage? If you're like me, an approach with the latter going wrong forces you to try another approach...or you could backtrack to regain health but that's less thrilling, heh.

Unless you're making an effort to backtrack and check for all the hidden extras, pathfinding generally isn't an issue, in spite of no map. One way pipes and which routes are open to you with your current abilities make it quick and easy to find the way forward. I wonder if the devs decided a mini/map would be immersion breaking for a ravenous inhuman entity. You always have a button to get an idea which way the nearest save point is, but I rarely used it myself.
The game always feels fair, as sound effects telegraph a gun's safety coming off, or a barrier going up, and visual indicators when you've dropped a size category. It certainly helps that the design of more dangerous enemies makes it easy to tell at a glance who is still a threat to you.

It's also worth noting how well-tailored for the experience the sound design is.

141157431.review:
While it's a very entertaining idea that clearly has a lot of thought put into the upgrades, story and general idea of the game, the levels constantly alternating between a metroidvania-like, exploration-driven game where you're encouraged to go back and redo things with the new upgrades and figure out your own path to an arbitrarily-handholdy experience where you're forced forward with no way back at all- not to mention the inconsistency where the save spots that unlock something and spit you right back out are visually identical to the ones that force you to a new area immediately, and the former becoming the latter once used once so they're not even usable for quick travel later.

Whoever did the design for the creature's gameplay itself did fantastically, as did whoever drafted the upgrades and where they are / the difficulty of getting them, but whoever actually did the level design should be ashamed of themselves for very clearly having talent yet being willing to throw it away completely every other level. This is also compounded by the two-forms system being theoretically a great idea yet not a single point in the game actually allows you to take advantage of it. There's just a few points where you need to downshift to solve a very obvious puzzle then go and get your mass back to continue, rather than having any exploration with alternate takes on how to handle situations. Sucks if you like the webbing upgrade because the need to break wood to be able to actually make it through the game means you're only allowed to use it when the game says okay.

I'd also argue the store description is a lie. It's not a game where you really do much stalking, you just have AI that's dumb as bricks so they act like they've no idea what's going on despite also very clearly being able to know exactly where you are at all times and respond to sounds more than two rooms away. That's not a bad thing, but not describing it as a puzzle game first and foremost is misleading- and the lack of transparency about it being a puzzle game plus how utterly short it is, for £17? Get it on sale or don't get it at all,

As to the DLCs - the OST is great, don't get me wrong but also incredibly samey and nondistinct. I couldn't possibly tell you where any part of the game the music is from, nor in a month or two could I even go "oh yes that's Carrion music" if not for the fleshy sounds included throughout. Not worth the £8.50.
Deluxe edition art book is neat, but also not worth a separate £9 either, and we're several years past a desktop wallpaper being something that's worth any monetary value at all so I'm opting to consider it a free bonus included with the art book, with the art book itself being the thing they're asking £9 for.

For me? Summer sale dropped it to £6.70, and that's a price that's fair, as is the deluxe edition bundle dropping to £7.60 (price not including base game). If the soundtrack were rolled into deluxe edition outright rather than having them be two DLCs, I'd feel happier with the pricing but the core game is just asking altogether too much. It's short, frustrating and feels half-baked and almost 100% of that is attributed to the shoddy level design, because the potential present with literally everything else can very much be felt. Steam also stopped picking up the game entirely a little over an hour into playing, my total playtime beating the game was slightly shy of two hours, in part due to giving up searching for the secrets when entering the gardens level.

141135466.review:
Huh. If you were one of the kids with your insides twisting in delight as a tyrannosaurus ate some dude cowering on a toilet in the middle of some ill thought out park somewhere, this game will give you the same vore delight.

However, once the novelty wore off, and you are some deliciously grotesque monster who sometimes sends legs flying like some man-eating Cookie Monster, the gameplay does become tedious. 

It becomes more of a puzzle-solving slog than a murderous rampage and it loses that original dopamine hit and becomes more of a case of dragging your butchers bin-bag of a body around a tedious maze network. 

I'd recommend it for the experience, and for those who enjoy puzzles with their murder. But I'm still awaiting a low-tech game purely for revelling in the primeval id.

140163530.review:
Stellar metroidvania horror. Can't recommend this enough.

Only issue I would mention is that level design can be a little difficult to navigate, and with no minimap or HUD to view the levels (which are all interconnected) it can be a bit easy to get lost.

Luckily Carrion makes up for that by being packed full of wonderfully honed mechanics, lovely (though macabre) sound design, and masterful vibes throughout its runtime. The sense of scaling and progression is very smooth and keeps the game consistently interesting.

Fair warning, this one's a bit on the short side, I took about 4 and half hours to beat the main story, and that was even after discovering most of the hidden areas, items, etc.

Regardless the monster is extremely entertaining to play, and despite being a metroidvania, I felt as though I had a lot of options available to me in which I could rip apart my enemies. 7/10

140027591.review:
TLDR:
The presentation of this game is incredible, the gameplay is satisfying, and the ending is one of the best I've ever seen.
Long version:
Carrion pulls of it's reverse horror theme extremely well. Enemies feel weak and vulnerable while still posing a genuine threat, and the way you destroy everything in your path gives a great feeling of power.
Moving around feels great, although it can get cumbersome when you reach larger sizes.
Navigation can be a bit weird, and the lack of a map led to me getting lost a few times. But the world is small enough to explore reasonably quickly, and it wouldn't make any sense for whatever it is you're playing as to have a map anyways.
Both combat, and general exploration takes the form of a series of puzzles, and they are generally fun to solve.
Obviously I shouldn't spoil the ending, but just know that it is thematically perfect. And while Carrion isn't a deep game in any sense, the final minutes of the game had me both in a bloodthirsty rampage, and dreading what I had just done.
Solid 8/10 would recommend

139002433.review:
I agree with some of the other (positive) reviews saying it's not worth $20, but only from a playtime angle. It doesn't seem like it has too much replay value (which is fine, not every game needs it), but it's got stellar art, sound design and music. In fact I think the short playtime can be seen as a plus. It's not a game that needs a lot of time to deliver its ideas, and it respects your time by not filling the game with a bunch of tedium to pad out the playtime. I see the full price tag as a way to pay the devs for their good work (but it seems to go on sale often enough anyways).

You can tell the artists and designers worked their asses off to get the environments to look as good and diverse as they are; to get the visual language down and polish the experience so that figuring out the game felt intuitive without sacrificing the satisfaction of feeling like YOU figured it out.
Messing around with the unique controls and movement is fun, and it gives you plenty of time and encounters early on to figure things out before it gets to the challenging parts.
Fights later on play out in ways that still feel open-ended and reward experimenting with your abilities without feeling like they're too easy, and the music during these really stands out to me as some of the best in the game.

My only real gripe with it is that I wish the hub area had a map of some sort, since you can end up spending very little time there between new areas, leaving it a lot harder build a mental image of how to get to older zones and grab stuff you missed, or to not accidentally backtrack when you're trying to get to the next one. They have some doors close behind you in sections you don't need to access again to help with this, but I think they ended up just making it harder for me to get my bearings, and sometimes momentarily made me think there were still areas I hadn't reached.

Other than that, it's a fun, short metroidvania with a streamlined flow. It delivers the satisfying highlights of getting new abilities, using them to get into old and new areas both, and figuring out how they can help you fight some of the harder enemies, without ever convoluting or drawing things out.
If you feel like supporting the time and thought that went into making all of that, buy it at full price. If you don't like that it took me only ~5 hours to 100% my first playthrough, wait for a sale.

138211423.review:
A somewhat intriguing spin on the Metroidvania genre, CARRION is a game that I almost forgot existed after I failed to try it out within my time on the Xbox Gamepass. 

Starting with the good, CARRION's artstyle and atmosphere are great. From the design of the playable creature, to the NPCs, and to the graphics, all of it is just a treat to look at. It reminds me a lot of Broforce in the graphics department.

Most of the gameplay I would count as okay. The puzzles are decent and the combat (while a little wonky) has some degree of freedom to it. Throwing objects at enemies doesn't seem entirely immersive, and somewhat more like I'm cheesing the game, but it is expressive and free in that regard. As for the puzzles, the main issue I had with them was the repetition of the "deposit" mechanic. Commonly, I would misclick and deposit more than was necessary and be stuck in a long, repetitive animation for some seconds. 

My main problem lies within 2 things, the lack of a minimap (which everyone seems to complain about), and the shocking lack of horror. Starting with the lack of a minimap... really? This seems like something that would be in the Game Design 101 class for Metroidvanias, and yet they completely forgot its inclusion. Secondly, I get that this is a "reverse horror" game, but after the first couple of kills the lack of psychological thrill really makes me feel like I'm missing something. The characters do not do more than scream incessantly, you can only rip them in half, and the gibs/blood are barely even noticeable. I was expecting to feel more like a villain while playing this game. Where is the horror? 

The music was just okay, nothing spectacular and it didn't add enough to the game in my opinion.

The ending was incredibly bland and left lots to be desired, 4 meh hours for 20 dollars isn't a great deal.

2.5/5, wouldn't really recommend for this price.

138020974.review:
Play as the monster for once, gliding through the dark, creepy hallways of a secret research base, devouring the pathetic humans who would keep you imprisoned.

Carrion's an excellent game with simple, fluid controls, great environmental storytelling, an excellent, context-sensitive soundtrack, and beautiful pixel graphics. It's a relatively short, sweet game, but that means it's the kind of game you can come back to every now and then when you're in the mood to be the monster for a while.

Honestly, if you don't own it already, why not? Go buy the thing already!

137918846.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- 16-bit-ish pixel art throughout gives vibes that are more Sega Genesis than SNES. Might have to do with the more mature content
- There's lots of lovely gore everywhere. Your character is a gooey, bleeding, toothy collection of chomping maws that leaves a trail of blood (and maybe half a body or two) in its wake
- The music is pretty good. The cueing for exciting bits is really well done and helps to ramp up the tension
- The sound effects are great. Tinkling glass, human screams, and crunching bones form an excellent auditory backdrop to the roars of your creature (frequently punctuated by explosions)

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- Being that you're a scary sci-fi beasty on a rampage, there's not a lot of overt narrative or dialogue. The game uses environmental storytelling to varying degrees of success to convey the background story underlying all the mayhem
- Leaving the player little breadcrumbs and clues is a fine approach to storytelling, but I always feel like I'm left with more questions than answers when all's said and done
- Carrion is very proudly a reverse horror game where you get to have all the fun as the scary monster. It's wholesome in that metal sort of way

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- I wouldn't say it's a platformer in the traditional sense as there's not really any platforming challenges. You just ooze around and solve door puzzles while wreaking mayhem on various scientific facilities
- The tentacle controls felt super awkward at first, but you get the hang of it pretty quickly
- You grow in size and ability as you munch on delicious humans (the ones without the shells, anyway). Each size level you reach comes with a different set of skills that you'll need to use to metroidvania your way through the map
- At some point, the game switches up the puzzle solving by making you switch between various sizes/abilities in order to progress. Sometimes this ramps up the challenge by putting you at a considerable matchup disadvantage against groups of enemies
- The level design is pretty good, and I like how the game sometimes presents you with different options on how to progress. Unfortunately, this means that you can sometimes find that your creature is too large to comfortably navigate some rooms. Still possible, but often very awkward

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- Will run well on most hardware
- An excellent Steam Deck game that performs well without fiddling with settings
- It's a short little snack that won't take you too long to beat. It limits the experience somewhat, unfortunately. At least the ending seems to suggest there will be a sequel that may tie up some loose ends

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]7.5/10[/b]. A simplified metroidvania that intertwines combat and puzzles in an interesting way. I just feel like I wanted a little bit more of everything the game offered, which was a little unsatisfying. Still a fun game, though

137915024.review:
The Good:
A perfect pitch; you are the shapeless horror from any one of a dozen classic 80s horror films, escaped (or set loose?) from a secret underground laboratory. Slither through air ducts, along metal grated corridors, and through concrete bunkers devouring all in your path. Adapt and overcome enemies, puzzles, and environmental hazards. Delightful, charming, and gruesome gore courtesy of excellent art direction and stellar sound design help sell the fantasy.

The Ugly:
The game follows the metroidvania design that has you backtracking to previously explored areas as you unlock new powers. This in and of itself is not a negative but the game lacks a map function and the warren-like maze of caves, corridors, and pipes can become more than a little disorienting. 
The controls can be a little haphazard when you're trying to grab onto a specific thing, be that a lever, enemy, or access grate in a crowded environment while under fire from enemies. On that note there are four enemy types in the entire game, not exactly a wide diversity, although I suppose enough for the games runtime.
And here is the true shortcoming of this game, it's short. Expect to 100% it in roughly 5 hours.

The Verdict:
A gore slicked romp through a fun pixel art world. Short game length, a lack of enemy variety, and no real story or challenge modes hold back what could be an intriguing premise of a more fully fleshed out experience. A true 7/10 game, pretty good, not bad. Wait for a sale.

137836365.review:
Great little metroidvania game!

Pros:
+ Great pixel art graphics and animations, especially the monster that you control in its various states of evolution
+ Unique, intuitive, fluid mouse movement control. Guiding the creature and using its momentum-based movement becomes second-nature in no time
+ Really immersive, atmospheric music / environmental sounds (that wouldn't feel out of place in any '80s horror movie)
+ Smart puzzles that are very well integrated into the level design. Each of the creature's three stages of evolution has unique abilities that must be used to go past the human and mechanical enemies as well as the various traps and barriers
+ The game [b]does not hold your hand[/b] (a rarity in this day and age). With no introduction, no clearly set objective, no map and no fast-travel, the player is left to explore and discover the world at his own pace. There are not-so-obvious signs scattered around that point towards key map points and the player will have to rely on the creature's echo-location ability to navigate the labyrinthine environment

Cons:
- The game is a bit on the short side, clocking in at around 9 hours (including hunting for all the extra abilities and the DLC)
- Other than a couple of playable 'cutscenes' that provide a glimpse into the past, there is no lore to explain the events that lead to the monster's existence or its motivations (the ending however is somewhat of a cliffhanger that lends hope for continuation in a new game)

137799555.review:
This is pretty good. Took me about 4.5 hours, steam's saying 2.8 now and I'm not sure why but I checked before and commented about it so someone so it used to be 4.5

You're playing a tentacle-y murder monster that eats people and tries very hard to eat robots. Controls are straight-forward - click to move in direction, right click to grab people and pull them in (or throw them around), various other abilities are unlocked as you play.

A unique aspect of the game is that your size and health bar are one and the same, and your current size determines the abilities you have available. Puzzle solving often revolves around working how to get yourself to a different size in the right part of the level, so that you can use that size's abilities. 

The rate at which you're introduced to new abilities is well-paced, with the application of the ability becoming apparent a short while before actually getting access to it, so you get this new thing and immediately know what to do with it. The puzzle solving clearly takes into account what abilities you'll have access to, and sets you up to employ them all in a fashion that makes you feel clever. 

Main issues I had:
 - You move so quickly through some parts of the map that I had a hard time building up a mental image of my surroundings for the first hour or 2. 
 - In your larger forms, in tight spaces, pieces of your body can get kinda stuck around a corner. Easily resolved by backing up, just a bit annoying.


I haven't looked at them, but there are modded levels to play on.

137798589.review:
There isn't anything WRONG with Carrion. It's a fine game. Very reminiscent of the arcade style web games that one would play back in their childhood, except much better polish. The mechanics are not very well described in the game but with enough fidgeting and experimentation you can figure out most of them. The controls are... fine. A bit janky once you get to max size.

 But that's just the issue I have with Carrion. It didn't do anything wrong-- in fact, it was  very fun! There were issues here and there but nothing particularly damning. A fine flash game on newgrounds. Except it's not. It's a $20 game. A $20 game that I 100%'d and got all 21 achievements including the full collectables... in 4.5 hours. Even getting it on sale for $8, I was left with a sour taste in my mouth. Less than 5 hours of gameplay? And that includes backtracking, upgrade-collecting, full completion, and even having a bit of fun stacking soldiers' bodies on top of each other then ripping them all around? It was FINE. A FINE free-flash game, one that I would even suggest $3 or even $5 for. $19.99 for a game that is just... over way too fast, is unacceptable. I loved playing it, but even as I beat it I was left with a bitter disappointment, thinking "... is that it? Are we moving on to a new facility? Or perhaps there are city-levels now?" Nope. Roll credits. 300 minutes of playtime for $10. Dave & Busters Arcade-level pricing.

137793844.review:
CARRION is a reverse horror game where you play as an amorphous creature of unknown origin. The game is a thrilling and visceral experience that lets you unleash your monstrous nature on the unsuspecting humans who imprisoned you.

The game features a stunning pixel art style and a haunting soundtrack that create a dark and immersive atmosphere. The gameplay is fluid and responsive, allowing you to control the creature with ease and precision. You can explore the facility, devour your enemies, acquire new abilities, and evolve into different forms.

The game is not very long, but it offers a satisfying and replayable experience that will make you feel like a true predator. The game also has some clever puzzles and secrets that will challenge your skills and curiosity.

CARRION is a game that subverts the usual tropes of horror and puts you in the role of the monster. It is a game that celebrates the power and beauty of being a terrifying creature. It is a game that I highly recommend to anyone who enjoys horror, action, and gore.

8 / 10

137761260.review:
I don't have a ton to say about CARRION, overall it was a really good game. I enjoyed playing as a vicious meat blob destroying and killing everything in my path. I did complete both the base game and the Christmas campaign to 100% completion in about 6 hours.

The gameplay is pretty good and the progression is well paced. CARRION does a good job of pacing the game and changing how you play as you go. It introduces new abilities for you to use just as you feel like you've gotten use to the previous one. The game never feels like it gets dragged out or padded for content. In terms of difficulty, I think that they've hit a good balance of just difficult enough to provide some challenge while also still being easy enough to make you feel like a powerful flesh monster.

The only negative thing I have to say is that navigating the map late game in order to get all of the abilities and achievements is a little frustrating without a map, I kept finding myself going around in the same loops while trying to get to a previous area of the game, but it's not that big of a deal, more of a minor annoyance.

I did see that there is a workshop section for this game, but it seems kind of barren. At the time of writing there is only 50 items in the workshop.

Overall I think that CARRION is worth playing if it seems like something that interests you. $20 may be a little steep for how long the game is and how soon you'd replay it so maybe pick it up on a sale.

137729580.review:
A love letter to sci-fi horror enthusiasts everywhere.

[✔] Being put in the role of a horror movie monster is a refreshing concept and it's executed well here. It does feel powerful - yet it's balanced enough that at the same time the player never really stops feeling vulnerable. Aspects of survival and challenge are never gone.

[✔] The way the creature looks, shifts and slithers around feels convincing within the deliberately retro graphics, while leaving some room for imagination.

[✔] Unique spacial perspective and the way the monster can quickly move in all directions is intuitive, satisfying and a pleasure to behold.

[✔] Atmosphere supported by great music and sound effects, with some neat subtle nods to / inspirations from genre classics.

[✔][b] / [/b][✖]  The game's fairly short, clocking at several hours (I'd say 4h for a normal playthrough, 6h when playing leisurely, and about 8h for an unhurried completionist run while keeping away from guides). Which is imo fine, however the price is a bit steep for that length and I'd personally recommend getting it on a sale.

[✖] One thing the game [b]desperately[/b] needed was some/any kind of map, or at the very least better indication which pathway/entry leads to what section. Progressing through the areas in order is (for the most part) reasonable - however, going back to previously inaccessible sections with new powers is very confusing, easily results in getting lost, and only gets more frustrating the greater the total unlocked game area becomes.

[✖] Minor issue, but the mentioned pleasure when moving around? At the monster's biggest size, it becomes a bit confusing and counter-intuitive, as its "centre of balance" you steer with isn't exactly at the front. Leads to occasionally going down the wrong hole, or getting shot because it's hard to account for the entirety of your mass. Not a big issue, perhaps even intentional to showcase the problems with [i]BIG[/i], but a slight annoyance all the same.

137656768.review:
[h1]Review: CARRION[/h1]
[h1]▬▬▬▬Una bestia imparable en un metroidmania.▬▬▬▬[/h1]

¿Recuerdas esas películas de terror donde había una fuerza imparable a la cual todo el mundo le tenía un miedo por lo increíblemente violenta que era la cosa? Bueno, mezcla ese tipo de cine de terror con un metroidmania y obtienes CARRION, el cual es un videojuego de terror en el que, efectivamente, tú eres esa fuerza imparable.
Su gameplay es lo más fuerte del juego, ofrece una movilidad de la criatura sublime y cómoda, estar explorando el escenario es bastante satisfactorio al igual que las formas que tenemos de destrozar, quebrantar y oblicuar a quienes nos rodean y huyen de nosotros.
El juego nos da una variedad de habilidades justas y necesarias para cada escenario, con un distinto enfoque de acción en cada una, sus mecánicas nos permiten tener una buena cantidad, comparada a la duración del juego, de opciones para limpiar cada sala a la que iremos avanzando.
El apartado audiovisual es sencillamente bello, el gore, la deformidad de la criatura están honestamente muy bien diseñados al igual que las instalaciones por las cuales vamos avanzando.
La historia está bastante bien y el final diría que es un chef kiss, me gusto bastante a pesar de ser un juego de maximo 6 horas de duracion.
[b][u]Sin embargo[/u][/b] hay una variedad muy escasa de enemigos a decir verdad, es cierto que a medida que se avanza aparecen más, pero al las últimas horas de juego son todos los mismos siendo sincero… Esperaba algo más de a decir verdad.
La falta de un mapa hace que te pierdas bastante fácil y hace que sea muy sencillo frustrarse, te obliga o bien a memorizar donde está cada cosa y que no has explorado, buscar una, guia, o revisar todas las salas por las cuales ya pasaste anteriormente, lo cual es [b]horrible.[/b]

[u]Calificación: 7.7/10, es bastante entretenido ser la bestia de la película de terror, los escenarios y el movimiento está muy bien hecho, pero… la falta de un mapa se hace [b]MUY[/b] notoria.[/u]

8/10

It's a cliché take, but the only real issue with this game is that there isn't more of it. Not in the sense that I felt snubbed by the playtime, It gave me a good seven hours of quality gameplay, but in the sense that I didn't want it to end. More game would of course have required further expansion of the mechanics, but there is definitely room for that within the concept. While some aspects of the game, like the story, are pretty light, they're all very well crafted for what is there, and they all serve their purpose to create a very cohesive experience. It's got the good kind of 80's sci-fi horror schlock vibe to it, and just as with the better examples of that genre, the hinting of more depth behind what we get explicitly told or shown gives it endless possibilites for expansion in future installments. I hope that's what we get here too.

137616263.review:
Carrion is utterly fascinating. At its heart, it is a puzzle game, with slight physics game traces, but you would never guess by its outer appearance. 

At the end of the game you will have three major forms, each with its own capabilities, and you can't change with them on the fly, but either have to consume biomass (ie, humans) or deposit some of your health at spawning pools in order to slim down and access your other set of abilities. 

Its cleverly designed and you will slithering around pipes and airducts in no time. So this is probably one of the most disgustingly fun puzzle games you will ever find. It also doubles as a power fantasy game, so whats not to love about it?

Just one thing: there is no map. The gameworld is rather tightly contained within an underground research lab, but there are still several different, distinct sections, pretty much like in any Metroid game, and you often have to backtrack in order to open doors that were unbreachable before, in order to unlock more and more abilities. And there is no real final area, where you can play around with your full set of abilities or ever really need them. There is a christmas DLC that sorta tackles this issue and that lets you start with your full set of abilities, but really, this is just nitpicking. 

All in all I really enjoyed my time as the unnamed parasite and would definitely come back for a second round.
