137603716.review:
It's not bad... but its not good either. 

Its not really a metroidvania game. For one you don't have a map. And everything looks the same. Its almost comical whenever a cutscene triggers to show you that somewhere a door opened. As if I remember where that was. I just randomly go through tubes until I spits me back onto the way forward. I remembered a line from Terry Pratchett's Only You Can Save Mankind: "Where does this airwent lead?" "I don't know" "How can you not know? I watched a movie once and the Alien always knew perfectly where it was on the ship!" "Well, they probably had a map then."

The combat is you holding right mouse button and grabbing people. The guys with electroshields need to be hit by a physics object first and then jammed into walls. That's the combat. Other abilites could theoretically be used in this "combat" but nothing beats holding right mouse. 

So really as a "game" the thing is not very interesting. But what about the reverse horror. This part of the game is even more lackluster. The humans do screem if they see you but they don't run away convincingly. And if you actually try to toy with your food the illusion breaks. I was sitting next to two unarmed women that were cowering in a corner and they would not try to run away because I was ontop of them and the game really wants you to insta kill everyone. Also the enemies do not react more intensely to seeing you eat a human than you just running past. And they have the typical AI of "oh I didn't see him for like 3 seconds. Back to walking around in circles."

Also the humans don't talk. No screaming "please don't kill me!" but also no chatter between the civilians. No "Damn, what mess has the Major send into this time?", no "I can't wait to go back to earth and marry Veronica!", or "It's in the walls! ITS IN THE GOD DAMN WALLS!"

So yeah: this game is mediocre in every aspect. Completely overhyped. There are better games that let you play as the Monster. For example Attack of the Earthlings.

137466039.review:
[b]Score: 5/10[/b]

Expectations are... a doozy, and you'll find yourself fairly quickly questioning the fairness of expectations within a few minutes of getting into Carrion. Despite the visual and tonal presentation of a movie-reminiscent monstrous horror, Carrion's actual gameplay comes as primarily puzzle solving and nigh-tactical action, with little story or narrative to assist in creating a horror or suspenseful experience. It's not what I "expected", but it's a competent pivot from something that may or may not have been more enjoyable (a question I hope won't go unanswered). The fundamentals of controlling a formless flesh beast are definitely very original, with a comfortable ease to sliding and zipping around between ventilation ducts and hallways, and the abilities are at least relatively inspired and fitting for the... protagonist, if you can really call it that. There's a glimmer of a deeper meaning with a few small playable cutscenes of presumably scientists unearthing something ghastly and ancient but it's not expanded on in any meaningful ways, nor does the beast ever gain the ability to read, which I wouldn't have minded even if just for a few little snippets of extra sauce. While an undoubtedly short game, I think the designers knew just about how long they could take the concept of the "flesh puzzle" ideas and bowed out at a respectable moment, but for me, it's easy to see where additional content could've been added without much adjustment to the whole picture. The last little stretch where they let you go hog-wild on some doomed workers is great, but it's the best example of what the game could've been, had the focus just been slightly different. Overall, a mutation or two could've made this a much better experience, but what is here is meaty enough for a decent time.

137211312.review:
hello! this is my review for the game carrion. i am not a professional and haven't played the full extent of the game such as the bonus unlock-able abilities and bonus math puzzles, that aside ive beaten the base game and the currently only dlc so hopefully my review can be of assistance, warning this will have some spoilers for the game such as powers and story line. 

also note- im aware there is a movie somewhere sharing the same name, or so ive heard- i don't know if this game if based off the movie and i don't particular think it matters for this review. as im more judging them off what i saw and understood from the game and not from other sources

[world building / lore]- there world building is clear and blunt along with there lore and general understanding, you are a unknown species of "monster" being studied in a lab when suddenly you escape and begin to terrorize the lab that's kept you prisoner such aka the frontier, its a very unique premise but it lacks a lot of information and ideas that would make it clear. it gives off a scp or major organization dealing with monsters and the abnormal but as far as i could find they only had you kept prisoner and didn't seem to be studying you, and strange samples you can adapt to that's not explained wether its parts of you gone missing or samples they had laying around the lab, but im getting of track. i think its blunt, straight and works well for the game-play and inst something that has a lot of lore or backstory shown on surface level, if your casual and don't think to much on it then dw about it. but i think it'd do really well to have more optional information, even something like having information about who runs the place and why they run the place, etc. but its easy to just make a head-cannon such as "there not necessarily into the abnormal there merely a large funded organization that studies anything that can better humanity", i think that works best considering a lot of the lab makes more sense such as there large number of weapons and scientists that don't seem like they have a lot of things to study, just saying adding more information even shadowing at more lore would've been a lot of fun. but maybe they had something in the movie i keep hearing about 

[appearance / visual aspects]- the games art is a lot of fun and while everything's pixels it works shockingly well, its nothing to gawk at but it feels like everything just works. it also isn't very stressful on your device and ran well on my old pass-me-down pc, the monster and "protagonist" looks very convincing and pretty cool if i can say so,

[adult or sensitive content]- if your prone to easy disgust or feeling bad after murder- then dont bother getting the game, your a monster and while some areas can be passed without murder- you will end up killing over and over again. and it has a level of gore, its all pixels but blood is slung everywhere and often you can bite people plainly in half and just damage them over all, it certainly is bloody and full of gore. it also is very violent and i know in this day and age there are people who are easily acceptable to aspects of fear and disgust, this is a reverse horror so if you cant handle horror elements (aside from jump-scares) then probably don't get it 

[audio- sound]- sound is excellent, and other then the choice to just make humans without weapons scream alot which made me kill them even when i didn't need to- it was amazing. the music puts you on edge despite you being the monster, the weapons sound incredible, the monster sounds like a giant flesh monster but they made it so its not unbearable or gross to listen to. i love how they make it sound like a horror game but with you playing it, and honestly it was a incredible feeling when the music spiked when i attacked after emerging from stealth. very good atmosphere and everything sounds natural and good 

[weapons / abilities]- abilities where A LOT of fun, and weapons where more smooth and entertaining to use then most shooter games in this style, i wont list them all because if you are reading this before playing the game i don't wish to ruin your fun. they where very creative and it was so much fun exploring ways to kill with these abilities, i do wish we got a lot more time to use some of them and id love if they added something like a skill tree or a evolution option to gain different abilities to give a lot more replay-ability and more things to do, for those curious you unlock abilities slowly threw out the game in different levels, most having a lot of purpose for different puzzles and killing methods, very entertaining but i wish there was... more, i also wish they buffed a few of the powers- some of the abilities felt insane and deadly but useful, while other powers like the beginning ability to roar felt useless 

[puzzles]- ngl, im not a puzzles man- ive owned games built around puzzles, i feel the same satisfaction when people solve them. but i despise puzzles in general because for me there sluggish and just annoying to get threw when you could be doing anything else, BUT im happy to report in this game they weren't to bad- other then being confusing at some parts they were creative and not repetitive enough that it was seriously entertaining or in the least didn't slow me down so much that it was slow, but it should be noted the whole map is progressed via different puzzles, such as learning how to open and operate different doors and using your abilities. 

[map- travel]- o boy, if the game is lacking anywhere majorly- its here... the level of rage and annoyance i had moving around this map is ridiculous. theirs no mini map and there is only a lack luster attempt at allowing you to locate your next goal, i think it adds more atmosphere with a lack of quests and game like menus of the sort but they could've done something with the ability echolocation, like you had a blank map but briefly saw around you or something with the ability- or just any clue to know where to go next. but no, a massive chunk of the game play was trying to find whatever the h-ll i was supposed to do next or where to go, a lot of time that could've and should've been spent on actual fun game play such as killing and a number of the puzzles, still- traveling wasn't horrible if you knew where you where going and the blockades where creative and you are fast, speedy and fit into areas that is fun to move around with- but i swear i did not need to spend 2 hours of that time finding out how the f--k where i was meant to go 

[AI / npcs]- fun and reasonable, only dialogue you get are screams and yelling but its honestly not something you need in a game like this. the guards shot at you and move carefully and not robotically, the humans cowered and it was fun to see them do so, many- to many met my wrath cause they didn't stop there screaming though. 

[ending/ pay-off]- going to avoid talking about the process and appearance as to keep away from spoilers, but its satisfying and pays off well. i do say it left me wanting more and to play around with my abilities a bit more, but honestly it was a good ending that took me (casually playing) around 5 hours to complete? not including the two hours it took to navigate when i was lost, and the dlc was a short but fun time and its free- it took me around a hour but i also played around alot and goofed off... 

overall id rate it a 8/10- its faults aren't few and aren't easily ignorable, and it can be irritable to play at times- but its game play was far to entertaining and the concept was way to good for me to rate it any lower. so ill deduct the two hours as points, and call it there. i really really hope to see more of this game and more interesting concepts dealt with it, such as maybe a co-op where you could even kill and hunt others of your kind with no little difficulty, almost like a predator vs predator fighting over there prey. or more abilites and a skill tree,

137181741.review:
A good example of reverse horror, lasting 5-7 hours. The levels are branched, there are puzzles, in some places you will have to go back to the areas that you can now go through.
But to be honest, it's still not quite what I expected after the trailer.

Among the advantages of the game, I can note the following::
[olist]
    [*] Genre itself, reverse horror is still not so common these days
    [*] Sound accompaniment, ambient is pleasant and works on the atmosphere
    [*] No difficult puzzles. Some consider this a disadvantage, but believe me, the game has several problems that, coupled with difficult puzzles, would make it unplayable for most people
    [*] Replayability, which is implemented through mods for new maps. Unfortunately, I didn't check the quality and quantity of custom maps, I only went through the main campaign and the Christmas DLC (which is super optional, by the way, you won't find anything new there)
    [*] Backtracking is here, but it's not so difficult (when you understand how it is implemented, but more on that below). You won't have to replay locations 5-7 times
[/olist]

Disadvantages:
[olist]
    [*] I lied >:) You [b]will have to[/b] replay locations 5-7 times. But for another reason - there is no map in the game. Okay, you say, how can a humie-eating tentacle monster have a map? Well, at least he(it?) could remember places he's already been to. Seriously, the second half of the game without a map turns into a series of endless situations when you don't understand where you are, where you should go and how to get back. By the way, it is because of this problem that I consider easy riddles a plus. In the absence of a map, it would be too much to puzzle over complex riddles in order to go further or get a new ability. This is the main gameplay disadvantage.
    [*] The game is not meaty enough. The trailer from the game situations is great and resembles a good-quality horror. The animated video is also good, but they exaggerate what will happen in the game. Initially, I expected that I would chase the surviving humans with a growl or secretly kill them so that no one would notice anything. In general, this is not how it works. You can really break into the room like a real monster and arrange a massacre there only in the second half of the game. There are practically no situations when you, in the best traditions of horror films, secretly and bloodily kills a victim who has separated from the rest. [spoiler] Infection with a symbiote does not count, at this point the game usually turns into an unassuming shooter [/spoiler]
    [*] AI is not very smart. You can catch the eye of a soldier and he will start shooting at you, but it is enough to hide from him for 10 seconds, he will forget about you and you can surprise attack him again. Is it a reference to Skyrim, like, "i guess it was just my imagination", right? Right? Right?
[/olist]

In general, as I said, the game is good. I would still like to add a location map, but I understand that the game is already 3 years old, most likely the developers will not make such major changes to it.

P.S. An important point that I didn't understand at first is that you can return to any location near the end of the game, the first half you just need to move forward.

8 tentacle meat monster in a toilet out of 10

136862375.review:
CARRION is a pretty fun game. You play as an experimental death creature meat thing whose goal is to gain biomass and escape the facility. That's the game in an overly simplified manner, but I think you got that from the trailers. I personally didn't expect this to be a Metroidvania when first starting it, but it turned out to be one of the most innovative Metroidvanias I've played to date; enough so that I think it blurs the lines on what can be considered as a Metroidvania. 

It has fun gameplay with a ton of engaging abilities with great applications. Some make you feel like a sneaky and conniving fiend, whereas others make you feel like an imposing mass of meaty death goo. The abilities, their uses, and the overall gameplay make you feel like a mass murderer, but in a good way.

As for the art style, I feel like it is really well done. The animations on your creature and the enemies you mercilessly slaughter really let you understand the terror that these people are likely feeling while also making you disregard the brutality of your actions with the help of the emotionless nature of your personal death abomination.

The story isn't too established in this game. You have some pieces of lore throughout the game, and it is pretty straightforward to piece these points together, but even once you piece the nuggets of lore together, you don't get much story in the end. Thankfully, CARRION doesn't need a fleshed-out story to make it a good game.

Overall, CARRION is a very fun and unique Metroidvania that makes you feel like a real menace. I highly recommend giving this game a try, as it makes slaughtering people so much fun!

136831674.review:
[h1]Tendril Slaughter[/h1]
Carrion is such a fun idea and its very well executed here! The main premise here is that you play as a grotesque monster that has to take over a research facility. You are a mass of flesh and tendrils and surprisingly that makes for a really entertaining control scheme. I would highly recommend playing on mouse and keyboard as this lets you swipe you're mouse around to fling yourself into doors, scientists, and vents!

The game plays out like any other metroidvania having you explore new zones and gaining new movement and combat abilities that unlock access to further areas. However Carrion really makes this feel fresh, you arent shooting, swinging a sword, or punching you're enemies. Instead you lash out with come bouldering in smashing into enemies, tearing them apart and eating them to gain mass! I wont reveal the later abilities but every one of them is fun to use, the game does a good job at making you think about how to use them to clear a room but doesn't make you slow down so much that the pace dies. 

The art is also a big strong point here. The environments are change from sterile to organic and I found them nice to explore. The main thing to take note of is the playable character. The animations look awesome and the pixel art style is used very well in this game. I don't think ill get to play anything with such interesting visuals for a while. 

Lastly I want to note the sound design. Its gross, its creepy, and its crisp. The sounds you make when eating is great and you'll hear it a lot so thats good! On top of that the ambient noises make for a very good atmosphere. You will also encounter lots of screaming through you're playtime and it never felt like too much or sounded too cheesy like some other games i've played. 

[b]In conclusion:[/b] Go ahead and treat yourself to this fun and unique take on the metroidvania formula!

135645567.review:
TLDR: A pixelated horror-styled game where you play as the antagonist, some flaws but still a pretty solid game, I'd say 7/10

[h1] Pros [/h1]

Any game that let you play as the bad guy automatically sparks my interest, this kind of concept have been done too little to be honest. Although this is technically not a horror game (coz you know, you ARE the horror itself), it never fails to convey the terror of the monster that you control. It's always groaning, splatting blood all over the place when moving, and I get the chills every time I hear the hellish screaming when I managed to breach the containment valves and escape into new areas. Oh, and the victims you just killed will always have some agonizing and painful death screams, just to make you extra bad lol.

One thing I really like is the graphical design of the game. I don't know why but pixelated styles are always fitting with horror game to me personally, I geuss it's probably because of the grittiness of the art style? Like when you're massacring people, it manages to tell what is happening but also not too focusing into all the minute details, vague enough for you to fill out the blanks, so less is more eh?



[h1] Nitpicks [/h1]

Speaking of designs, the game's map design is basically a maze, it revolves around you finding a way to escape the research facility, which is a great way to kick in the atmosphere, makes you feel isolated, abandoned. You know, typical cosmic horror stuff... 
But one of the main issue I noticed about this design is backtracking without any maps. Okay personally, I have no problems with backtracking, I've played hollow knight so this kind of backtracking is mild (just that other people might found it frustrating), my problem is just that there's no map for viewing, sometimes it feels like I have to trail my path back and forth needlessly, again and again just to make sure I am heading the right way. Not to mention that some of the areas are blocked forever once you finishes so it kinda messes up your memory of where you wanna go, so it kinda disrupts the game flow. 
It's okay if you wanna let the player to learn the paths, you don't even have to show their location at all, but at least put the map on specific places and let the player know how big is this place exactly, this should make the players less overwhelmed by the map design and improves the sense of progress in the game.

Another nitpick I had is that the monster's special skills are useful only in specific occasions, like really the only time I use them are when I'm in puzzle maps, which in that aspect works perfectly fine, and I enjoy my time solving the puzzles to get fulfilling rewards. But in other areas, those special abilities are just not that helpful, as the energy slots uses up pretty fast, it couldn't display its potential when it comes to combat. 

Oh and the combat, I feel like the game had too few enemy variety, like in the late game we only got 2 ([spoiler] shielded flamethrower soldiers and shielded attack drones[/spoiler]), which makes some of the challenges in combat kinda lost in the late game since you're too powerful to be stopped. But I understand it's a short game (if I didn't do any backtracking I think i'd have finished the game in 3 hrs), so it's a bit hard to polish the difficulty curve. I just think that maybe adding a final boss battle or new types of enemies in the final part of the game could raise the stakes more and make the endgame more entertaining, perhaps you need to fight a different specimen, or a giant death robot driven by the remaining survivors or some sorts...

Overall, Carrion is a pretty compelling game, it had great artstyle and game concept. Although not being utilized to its fullest potential, it manages to make a horror-based game quite enjoyable. A round of applause to the Development team for making this short but fun horror game!

Great concept and art but the game design is unbearable. 

Puzzles are mostly based on backtracking to change abilities or finding where to go, nothing that really makes you think. 

Combat gets close to fun but it's pretty shallow, they try to make it difficult by adding enemies that kill you quickly and can't be hit from the front, but the solution is almost always to hide and surprise them. In writing, this sounds kind of fun but almost every encounter is like that. Furthermore, gore is limited to only one type of enemy and even then all you do is cut them in half.

It isn't really difficult, but there's plenty of cheap ways to die by not noticing something, slipping with the clunky movement or getting carried away trying to have fun during combat. Death is punished by being sent back to a checkpoint, which are spread out pretty stupidly.

It's just drudgery. Unless you're really sold on the themes, it all just feels like a chore.

135173452.review:
True to its description: "a reverse horror game in which you assume the role of an amorphous creature"
This time you are the monster in the vents and it's exhilarating to jump out and devour the unsuspecting humans.
But initially you are weak and a guy with a gun can kill you, so you have to be careful and avoid direct conflict. And as you progress you gain new mutations (there are just your skills needed for a metroidvania) and your goal is to escape the facility you're held captive in.

Graphics are good (i personally like these types of slightly pixelated 2d games)
Gameplay is good (i played with a controller), moving about is mostly easy, but grabbing enemies requires a bit of precision.
And the story is ok, mostry delivered through flashbacks with minimal dialog.

134786880.review:
I haven't even beaten the game yet, but after <2hrs of play I am so impressed. The creature you play as moves so fluidly, and the controls are intuitive and easy to pick up which makes that movement even better. This game absolutely NAILS the "you are the monster" feeling and it's so damn fun while also piquing your curiosity about the story. There's something so satisfying about coming into a room of armed enemies and figuring out the best way to get rid of them, whether it be sneakily snatching them from a vent or barreling at them like an angry plate of spaghetti and meatballs.

Progression is very smooth and well-paced. You unlock new powers over time which both open up more areas and improve your monster's killing toolkit. My only gripe is that occasionally I got a bit lost while trying to find my way around, but overall the game does a solid job of keeping you on track. The puzzles are straightforward so I found little frustration with them.

Definitely a 9.5/10 if only because I'm stupid and kept getting lost. Absolutely a fantastic game, and it looks like there's even more to do after you beat the main story because this game has Workshop support. I got it on sale at ~$8 and it was worth every penny.

The game is amazing no questions asked. 9/10
The pixel art is just so wonderful and the colors are beautiful.

The story is plenty confusing which might be a good thing though I wish more was explained. (I was very dissapointed that we only got 3 flashbacks)

The gameplay is pretty easy and what I like about the combat is that you can deal with in multiple ways. You can be sneaky and take out enemies one by one, or go full rampage and kill everything in sight.
The puzzles were pretty good and I had quite a bit of fun with them.

There's not much content to this game as I finished it 6.3 hours.

My biggest gripe with this game however is that there's no map, though it's not that bad since levels are small and areas are distinct enough that you'll never get lost.

Also pog for polish developers. Didn't even know it was made by my fellow poles until I got to credits.


Over all I can definitely recommend this game. Maybe on sale though, as the price is a bit much.

134387174.review:
"Carrion" is a reverse-horror game developed by Phobia Game Studio and released in 2020.

Gameplay: The gameplay of "Carrion" puts the player in the role of a monstrous creature who must escape from a research facility and wreak havoc on the humans within. The game features a unique movement system that allows the player to slither, crawl, and squeeze through tight spaces, as well as a variety of abilities such as tentacle attacks and the ability to mimic objects. The game is fast-paced and action-packed, with satisfying combat and challenging puzzles. However, some players may find the game's lack of variety in gameplay and short length disappointing.

Story: The game's story is minimalistic, with no dialogue or cutscenes, but the player can piece together the events of the story through the environment and encounters with NPCs. The game's atmosphere is eerie and unsettling, with a sense of isolation and desperation.

Graphics and Sound: "Carrion" features impressive pixel art graphics, with detailed environments and gruesome creature designs. The sound design is also effective, with atmospheric sound effects and a haunting soundtrack that adds to the game's horror elements.

Replayability: The game offers some replayability, with the ability to replay levels and unlock additional abilities. However, the lack of variety in gameplay and short length may limit replayability for some players.

Criticism: "Carrion" has been criticized for its lack of variety in gameplay and short length, which may not provide enough content for some players. The game's minimalist storytelling may also be disappointing for some players who prefer a more narrative-driven experience.

Overall, "Carrion" is an excellent game that offers a unique and engaging experience for fans of the horror and action genres. The game's impressive graphics, effective sound design, and fast-paced gameplay make it a must-play for those looking for a different take on the horror genre. While its lack of variety in gameplay and short length may be disappointing for some players, its satisfying combat and challenging puzzles make it worth checking out for anyone who enjoys a good horror game.

133538221.review:
[code]Puedes ver más reseñas como esta en la mentoría [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34129733/][u]PIXEL 404[/u][/url][/code]

[h1]Es bueno ser malo[/h1]
Si llevas un tiempo en el mundo de los videojuegos y tienes algo de culturilla general sobre el tema, y no vienes del mundo de las consolas, sabrás que la frase “Es bueno ser malo” (Evil is Good) se creó en 1997 como eslogan del juego Dungeon Keeper, el cual creó un antes y un después en cierta tendencia de muchos títulos posteriores para que el jugador fuera el “malo y el mal” en la historia, sin ambages ni decisiones morales de última hora. Eres el “malo” y punto. Algo que antes no era ni mucho menos la norma, y en cierta manera era hasta un tabú. 

Particularmente, la traducción al español de esa frase me parece infinitamente mejor que la original en inglés, porque incluye la dicotomía bueno-malo dentro de la misma frase (chupaos esa, anglófilos). Sea como sea, y rolletes de abuelete aparte, Carrion es un “Es bueno ser malo”, y lo hace realmente bien.   

[h1]Al más puro estilo John Carpenter[/h1]
En el juego, tomaremos el control de una masa de carne informe que escapa de su unidad de contención dentro de un laboratorio secreto subterráneo. A partir de ahí…, venganza y muerte.

Al principio comenzaremos como un ser pequeñito y adorable de grandes mandíbulas y pequeños tentáculos para ir posteriormente creciendo hasta convertirnos en una auténtica bestia atroz de varias docenas de metros de tamaño. Y para conseguirlo, lo que debemos hacer es explorar las instalaciones, conseguir mayor poder consiguiendo mejoras e ir desmembrando y mutilando a todo humano que se nos cruce por el camino. Y créeme, está muy bien conseguido y es muy satisfactorio.

[h1]La presa se convierte en cazador[/h1]
Una de las mejoras cosas que tiene Carrion, por no decir la mejor, es que tiene la virtud de hacerte sentir que tú eres el cazador y que los humanos son meras alimañas que merecen ser partidas en dos para ser devoradas posteriormente.

A esto ayuda enormemente que cuando te ven aparecer en una sala empiezan todos a correr y a chillar como locos, con unos efectos de sonido realmente conseguidos. Claro, al oír los gritos pues te vienes arriba y piensas: “Corre, corre, que no te va a servir de nada”. Y efectivamente, segundos después el o la que gritaba yace en el suelo en dos trozos. 

Sin embargo, si esto fuera así siempre el juego perdería la gracia rápidamente. Es por ello que mientras más avanza la aventura más peligrosos serán los humanos con los que nos encontremos. Algunos con pistolas, pero otros con ametralladoras o lanzallamas, e incluso con cosas peores.

Está mal que lo diga porque es el personaje que controlas, pero cuando lo queman con un lanzallamas y empieza a chillar es bastante divertido, primero porque está muy bien hecho, y después porque te vas a dar patadas en los tentáculos buscando agua para no quemarte por completo.

[h1]La clave de todo es el movimiento[/h1]
Una de las dudas que pueden surgir, y era una que yo tenía, es saber si el control de nuestro monstruo informe era cómodo y estaba bien hecho, y lo cierto es que está realmente bien ejecutado ese aspecto.

Al principio se hace un tanto raro, pero al poco tiempo ya estarás totalmente acostumbrado a desplazarte por todo el escenario y a utilizar los múltiples poderes que irás acumulando durante tu periplo de venganza. Así que, en ese aspecto, todo funciona a las mil maravillas y no tienes por qué preocuparte.

[h1]Debajo de tanta matanza hay una historia[/h1]
Además de pasártelo pipa desmembrando a la peña, el juego se toma su tiempo para contarte la historia que se oculta detrás de este ser. Hay determinados flashbacks que te pondrán en situación, y aunque no entran en excesivos detalles (tampoco es necesario), sí que sirve para situarte un poco dentro de la historia, y además el final es épico.

Sí que es cierto que la historia como tal, los flashbacks, no vienen porque sí y tendrás que buscarlos por la base, pero tampoco serán nada complejos de encontrar. Además, el juego juega mucho con el backtracking (volver a visitar escenarios ya visitados, pero con nuevas habilidades que nos permiten el acceso a nuevas partes del mapa) y en cierto modo podría decirse que el juego tiene unas fuertes dosis de metroidvania. 

Sin embargo, esto es algo puramente opcional en la mayoría de los casos y sirve más para el tema de logros que como algo indispensable para acabarte la aventura. Por lo tanto, hay componente metroidvania, pero no es un metroidvania propiamente dicho ya que el backtracking es opcional. Aun así, yo recomiendo el backtracking, ya que si no el juego puede durar unas 4-5 horas como mucho y pierde bastante encanto por algunas cosas que dejas sin descubrir.

[h1]Aspecto técnico bastante cuidado[/h1]
Como ya habrás podido ver por las capturas y vídeos el juego es puro pixel art, y lo cierto es que está muy bien hecho en casi todos sus aspectos. A destacar especialmente, y como no podía ser de otro modo, las animaciones de la criatura al desplazarse, ya que son rápidas y están muy bien realizadas.

Su música es otro aspecto tremendamente importante, y te ayuda a meterte en situación enormemente. Pero en este caso, esa musiquilla de suspense que suena no te agobiará a ti, sino que hará que te vengas más arriba para seguir cazando. Es algo curioso cómo cambia la película cuando tienes una docena de bocas con colmillos afilados y tropecientos tentáculos a cada cual más mortal.

[h1]Conclusiones[/h1]
Por todo lo dicho, Carrion es un juego prácticamente único en su especie, nunca mejor dicho. Ofrece una jugabilidad tremendamente entretenida, muy dinámica y llena de sorpresas, y además de todo esto, técnicamente está muy bien realizado. De hecho, creo que es un juego que debería jugar todo el mundo para entender totalmente la frase que dijo Shigeru Miyamoto de “Incluso los monstruos tienen un motivo y una razón para ser como son”. Qué gran verdad, y de hecho da qué pensar sobre quien es el monstruo realmente en toda esta historia. Pero para eso, tendrás que descubrirla antes.

133437953.review:
For me, the pros outweigh by far the single con, so I recommend it without doubt.

Pros: the movement of IT is amazing, it feels so organic and strangely satisfactory to move around and use the habilities. The pixel art, sound and animations are all incredible.
After abandoning midgame soooo many great but too large or repetitive games like AC: Origins or Chorus, I felt a sweet satisfaction knowing the progression of the game [spoiler]the number of containment units breached[/spoiler] and finishing it in 9 hours. So much that I felt right writing this review.

Con: as stated by everyone, the lack of map. I could understand it if the level design was adjusted accordingly but it seems almost inevitable to get lost in a loop of "what am I missing, what was I doing, is it the 3rd or 6th time I come by this closed door??"

132955579.review:
Carrion is a interesting take on the classic explore/powerup/combat formula found in metroidvania type of games. That being said it most definitely leans toward the explore part of that formula more then anything else. Combat is more a puzzle type of scenario  and Powerups are generally required to continue exploring. 
The Game itself is fairly simple and generally can be completed in a few hours. Controls are rather spotty  and music/sound is rather lowkey.

That all being said I actually rather enjoyed the game. It is a fresh take on the metroidvania/adventure genre It fits right in with my twisted sense of self and takes  some very heavy inspiration from one of my favorite movies. John Carpenter's The thing. 

As I mentioned the controls are a bit spotty but I feel they don't break the game. I would of preferred WASD controls as a option, but lack of them doesn't make it to difficult as it rather simple overall.

Sound/music I generally is one of the biggest things I rail on but in this case the lack of variety actually enhanced  the feel/mood of the game. It makes it more alien? other? something like that. It helped set the mood and made me feel I was something else.

Decent steam workshop and mod integration but it does seem to suffer a lack of content there. However, I'm willing to over look that as the game is more of niche type of game and does fall more on the weird side then mainstream side. 

Gameplay its fairly solid. Enter the area explore the area figure out how to get to the bio container. Removing/adding biomass to change which abilities you have I felt was a nice touch.

A few things I do wish was some type of map or ability to see where you are.I'm not asking for a super detailed map but maybe something that says you are in this area type of thing. Second was some more collectibles/Notes that type of thing. This is a research base your in, it would make sense to have some type of data logs or something we could collect .

Overall I give a it a solid 7/10. Which leads to the question of is it worth the asking price. At the time I am writing this it  is currently 20$ USD. As much as I would like to give a firm Hell yes  it is worth that price, I can't. The game was fun and I do recommend it  but I feel that it is falling just shy of the bar needed to justify a  20$ price tag.  I would recommend waiting till it goes on sale or a price drop

132437248.review:
I'm not usually a big fan of 2D platformers but I loved the concept of reverse horror and playing the part of the monster that is attempting to escape captivity so I gave it a go. 

And wow, this game completely sold me the concept of metroidvania having never really played one before. I usually don't like backtracking in games, but in this I actually enjoyed traipsing back through the areas that I had caused havoc in earlier and remembering the routes I had taken through the levels because the movement is so fluid and joyous to control. I didn't feel like the game was wasting my time at all, which was really refreshing.

The art is gorgeous and really gives an excellent 16-bit or early 90s PC vibe which my nostalgia lapped up! Again, the animations and movement is exceptionally well done and feels so nice to play.

I was a bit disappointed when the campaign ended around 8 hours in (and that was me really taking my time to enjoy every second of it and also doing the free winter DLC), however I thankfully found out that on the workshop is several lengthy modded campaigns, one of which is extremely high quality and gave me nearly another 6 hours of fun with this game! So if you do get this game and enjoy it, definitely check out the modded campaigns, it made up for an otherwise relatively short story mode.

This is one of those games that I truly hope there will be a sequel or a couple of games that are inspired by it because it was a complete breath of fresh air.

131793714.review:
Would have chosen "neutral" if that was an option, but between "positive" and "negative" I'm slightly more on the "positive" side.

"Carrion" is a very unique concept, and it's fun to play. The controls are also very unique and the visuals look very nice too, the animation on the creature looking particularly great. But there's one major issue: the whole game is one giant maze. Everything looks similar, and it's difficult to tell where you need to go. And even if you DO know where you want to know, it's hard to find your way there, often resulting in you going in circles. The game could really do with a map or a re-design to make it less of a series of identical-looking tunnels. 

Overall, it's worth checking out for the unique concept, but as an actual game, the irritation of the game's maze-like levels make it a chore to play.

131767288.review:
This game is fun with a side of wasted potential.

The idea is great, the art is great, but the gameplay has a couple of shortcomings.

[b]The good[/b]
[list]
[*]Great idea of playing a disgusting monstrous blob wreaking havoc on a research facility

[*]Animation, art, and physics are very well done. The movement is very satisfying and smooth.

[*]The designers perfectly captured how to make the player feel like a terrifying, disgusting monster. The gross eating sounds, or the sounds of you breaking through the vents into a room of screaming innocents, tossing their bodies around and piercing them with spikes.. The physics, sound design and visuals of combat are all great.
[/list]
[b]The bad[/b]
[list]
[*]The game gives you no opportunity to get creative. Apart from finding containment units, it is remarkably linear. I kept trying to find hidden nooks and crannies, secrets, easter eggs, alternative approach, or perhaps arriving at the result in a different manner than the game intended. Nope, you're firmly on the tracks, keep your arms and legs in the vehicle at all times. Then again it's an indie game made by a tiny team, so ofc I didn't expect an RPG with 5 endings. Just a little bit of flexibility.

[*]The level design and lack of a map can turn this into a very disorienting game if you don't play it in one go. Luckily the game is very short, but the similar-looking areas don't help your sense of orientation whatsoever. I played it over one weekend and I got lost a couple of times. It wasn't a huge deal, I just don't see how not including a map made the game more enjoyable in any way, since it's not a metroidvania.

[*]The actual mechanics of combat aren't amazing. The enemies are either barely a threat, or you run from them and try to fight from max distance/out of line of sight. This isn't a big issue, just wish there was some middle ground between "haha me eat the screaming lady with a handgun" and "S.HIT HE HAS A FLAMETHROWER, GET THE WATAH"

[*]The mechanic of making yourself smaller to use different abilities isn't a bad idea, but the backtracking to find water to dump your biomass just makes it a pain in the mass.
[/list]

[b]TL;DR[/b]
Overall it's a fun game, fun idea, great art, very short, and has a couple of design shortcomings that made me wonder what could've been.

131385060.review:
Review title: Attack of the writhing (formerly flying) spaghetti monster. 

It's good. In this build back better economy I wouldn't say it's [b][i] 20$ [/i][/b] good. But, it's def 10$ good, 15$ good if you [i]really[/i] like the genre. It's fairly easy. I made it most of the way through the game without dying once, then once the difficulty stepped up and I started dying near the end, so long as you save at the right places and times, you don't really lose much, and it's not really frustrating. The puzzles can all be solved via brute force trial and error, however, the very end was really confusing. I had no idea how to beat the game 

VERY MINOR SPOILER [spoiler] You basically end up with the whole facility opened up, and you can spend hours wandering around till you find out where you need to go to acquire the special upgrade that makes the game winnable [/spoiler]. 

But a quick google search gave me the clue I needed and I figured it out for myself the rest of the way. 

Overall, I wish there were more games from this monsters perspective, a 3d action version of game for example would be legit. but the 2d metroidvania action of this game is still very good. It really reminds me of old school 8 bit and 16bit games for all the right reasons. Some would say it's too short, and I can say that it is definitely on the shorter side. My play time (5.6) hours includes the DLC. For some this is a bad thing, but I don't mind, I didn't find ALL the stuff, and I often don't have time to spend 40+ hours on a full length game these days. 

My biggest complaint is that the game is a labyrinth, and they don't give you anything that even remotely serves as a map. But the path of destruction and bloody gore you leave in your wake does kind of serve as a trail of breadcrumbs, so you can explore and know you have been somewhere because enemies and the environment are obviously changed by the beasts passage. 

One of the neatest things is the attention to detail with the little sprites of the people and their activities, their screams, and how you will see them sitting on the toilet right under an air vent where you can reach in with a death noodle tentacle and control their minds or kill them. And part of the fun is devising neat ways to kill your enemies. I cannot stress just how OP you are compared to most things in the game, some scenes you are basically a giant wrecking ball that just smashes, eats, and tears apart a room in very satisfying ways. 

All in all, wait for a 30% or more sale, unless you REALLY like games like this. I do, so it was worth the 20$.

131331946.review:
[h1]A fun, refreshing, and short horror game with a couple of flaws [/h1]

I might be a bit late to the reviews and I don't have that many hours, but I've gotta say, I love horror games, and If you do too you'll like this new take on the genre.

this'll be a quick review, I mostly just wanted to show my appreciation for the game with a composition of my thoughts as It's really one of a kind. Anyways, here goes.

[u]Gameplay/What to expect[/u]

Carrion's premise is creative and refreshing; Instead of outrunning a monster in the shadows, you are that monster. 
You can play however you want; you can be stealthy and use your abilities to control people and kill from the inside using their weapons; lurk around and wait for people to munch on from the ceiling; or even just rush in, mutilate, and crush a bunch of guys.

Carrion's combat mechanics are fun and exceptionally gruesome (you can eat half a guy and vomit up his stomach acid!!!!), similar to that of BUTCHER's, a game also made by phobia game studio, (I recommend you check it out if you liked carrion.)

The artstyle is phenomenal and really allows for some great procedural animations for the monster, as well as cinematic and graphic battles against the facilities' members and their various machines that try to kill you.

[u]Some issues[/u]

There are a couple issues with the game, as detailed below, but one thing that really stuck out to me was the lack of guide for the game's map. Don't get me wrong, the game looks great and is fun to explore, but I seemed to get lost quite frequently, especially when backtracking and in order to find those pesky vials. [u](This can easily be fixed by just finding some maps online though)[/u]

I feel as though there were some missed opportunities with the game, such as a lack of NG+ or even re-visiting battles in the same save, as I felt murdering humans was one of the main focuses of the game, so having to restart to experience these fights was a bit of a let-down. The semi-recent integration of the workshop to the game makes up for these issues, allowing for some fun, player-made campaigns and skins for your red meatball guy. 

so basically eat humans as the reincarnation of the flying spaghetti monster and solve a couple of puzzles along the way

130926741.review:
[b]Carrion[/b] is a short, 4-5-hour MetroidVania title where the hook is that you play as a sentient blob of carnivorous biomass, and the "dungeon" you're delving is the research base that was supposed to contain you.  The main gameplay conceit that being a blob brings to the table is that you grow whenever you feed and shrink whenever you take damage, and different abilities lock and unlock at different sizes.

For instance, in your small, unfed form, you only take a few hits to kill but you have access to a web-shooting ability that lets you press buttons and grab things from very far away, even on the other side of otherwise-impenetrable barriers.  At medium size, you get a bull rush that lets you knock down certain walls, but you lose the web throw.  At large size, you're too huge to properly build momentum within the cramped confines of the base (ergo: no wall bash), but you get an armor shield that lets you shrug off the automated guns that normally instakill you in certain areas, and so forth.

Each form has several such abilities, all of which have environmental utility (as well as being fun to torment humans with), and so puzzles get increasingly complex and multifaceted as the game goes on.  Rarely are you just blindly tearing humans apart with reckless abandon; they're too useful as size-shifting resources for the puzzle gameplay, and even the combat encounters are frequently designed [i]as[/i] puzzles, like those above-mentioned instakill turrets.

On that point, something that may surprise players coming into the game expecting cathartic monster destruction madness is that it's almost entirely puzzle-based, with shifting in size to access different areas and unlock different options making up almost all of the gameplay.  For instance, say that there's a destructible wall in front of another, porous wall, behind which is a lever that gates progression.  You would need to eat enough people to be medium-sized, then bash down the wall, then go take some damage to shrink, then use the web shooter to hit the lever.

In short, for a game about being an evil brainless meatball, it's surprisingly cerebral, and its jarring (but [i]very[/i] "Devolver Digital") juxtaposition of gory ultraviolence and patient puzzle-solving won't be for everyone.  For me, though, it hit a nice sweet spot.  Buy it when it's on sale for 15 bucks and you won't be disappointed with the amount of entertainment it brings for the price.

130552083.review:
I've had Carrion in my steam library for over a year now, I decided to finally go ahead and give it a shot. I'm not sure what had drawn me to it in the first place but I think I had just finished playing Bro Force and wanted another pixel based game but never got a chance to play it until now. I can easily say Carrion is 100% unique to any thing else I've played. You get to play as a tentacled bio-mutant monster who wreaks havoc on it's creators and anyone else that's in it's way. Let's jump right into the pros and cons.

Pros:
* As I just mentioned, it's unique to any other game I've played so far. It's fast paced like BroForce, you can both die and kill quickly, but obviously in this case you are playing as the monster. There are other games reviewers have mentioned that Carrion is similar to but I've not played them. I'm saying this game is unique more so because of the actual game play.
* It's fun to be the villain sometimes, and in Carrion you are an escaped bio-mutant, so actually I'm not sure you are villain so much as a creature trying to pay back everyone who was involved with it's creation and exploitation. It's fun to munch on humans and rip them to pieces, after all they did deserve it!
* As the bio mutant, you gain powers as you play however at a cost. When you gain a new power you also gain mass AND you lose access to your previous power. When you gain mass you also become much bigger, easier to shoot and to be seen. Sometimes that can spell trouble for you. But one nifty mechanic in the game is you can shed your mass in certain areas in order to regain old abilities. This is something you will do quite often to solve puzzles or avoid enemies. You also can return to the mass you shed and reabsorb it OR you can just feast on more enemies and gain your mass back. FYI, your mass is also your life gauge. 
* Puzzles are interesting and engaging and from what I've played so far, they've all been different
* It's challenging but not too challenging to the point where in other games I've just grown frustrated and quit. Carrion I will continue to play and likely finish mostly because it's fun!

Cons:
* One major draw back is, I think it's quite confusing at times what you are suppose to be doing. There isn't a tutorial and not much hand holding at all. You sort of have to wonder around aimlessly until get your bearings. Once you do, and realize where to look and how to find things it becomes a lot easier. BUT, I think that could be a turn off to people because, I'm not sure how long someone will fiddle around trying to figure out what to do before they are frustrated and quit. 
* This gripe is also tied into my previous issue, yes it's confusing to know what to do but also jeeez it's hard to see items and make distinctions between things. I don't want to give away too much information, but there are hidden entrances, doorways, pipes and also there are levers and switches and things you need to use. With Carrion being a pixelated game, it's not particularly easy to see things. They are not obvious enough in my opinion. 
* No Map, even a mini map would be nice. It would eliminate a lot of my back tracking because I can't remember where something was.

All things considered my list of complaints are negligible, I think that the average player will probably enjoy Carrion. Mostly they are quality of life complaints, would be nice to have but doesn't ruin the game. The cool mechanics and the fun atmosphere are enough to push this game easily into the thumbs up category for me. I'm not sure on the $20 USD. It seems maybe a little high, but given that I've enjoyed 2 hours of the game so far and plan to continue to the end, I don't think you'll be upset paying full price, but if you have your doubts get it on sale.

130353440.review:
Carrion is a Metroidvania/puzzle game where you play as a shapeless blob of teeth, eyes, blood, and gore, and you explore a military/science/military science complex while murdering and/or eating every human in sight. 
The graphics are pixely and retro, but very clearly modern in the lighting and effects. The game looks really good for what it is.
The gameplay is smooth, and the movement feels wonderful as you whip around tight tunnels and more expansive caverns with uncountable tentacles. 
The game is relatively short, but enjoyable all the same; after a while the puzzles start getting repetitive, but the game introduces new mechanics every so often to keep things fresh. The combat is quite interesting--despite being a monstrous abomination, you start the game rather weak, and have to rely on ambush tactics to not get shot to death. Later on, as you get more abilities, the power level of the enemies ramps up as well, so the combat stays feeling fresh the whole game.
The story is...somewhat anemic, but for what the game is, I think it works really well. You get bits of lore in flashback sequences where you control a human, and quite a bit remains unclear at the end of the game, but I didn't mind that--story wasn't what I was here for. And while what story there is is quite interesting, it doesn't make me feel like I missed out.

All in all, probably my third favorite game of all time. 10/10, wish there were more games where you get to play as a hungry shapeless blob of meat and terrorize the military and civilians alike.

130311148.review:
Great game to get on sale. It's unique, sometimes a little janky dealing with enemies, but otherwise good fun. 8/10. 

The only real complaint I have is it was way too short. I would've liked to see the game get developed into a longer title, or maybe a sequel that'll be at least 2-3x in length. Once you get proficient at the mechanics and puzzle-solving, it's over in a few hours. The extra holiday mission was a welcome extension, but was only an hour long. I finished the base game and the extra mission in a Saturday evening.

The more minor complaint is the map got a little confusing after a while, and I had to find some guides for collecting some final achievements, because I had no idea how to reach the earlier zones once I was near the end. Clearing a level is relatively straightforward, and exploring the whole thing is somewhat of a requirement, because you need to hit all the "checkpoints" to open the door to the following zone, but the collectables were often blocked by tools/abilities you didn't have yet, in random parts of the level. So not only was it you had to go back to the previous zones after getting said ability, but you also had to navigate a majority of a level you hadn't seen for several hours to find the barred path again.

Maybe this is more irritating than I thought, that I'm writing so long about it. Essentially, backtracking was a bit of a chore, and could've been done better. They had some exit signs for where the portals to next zones were, but the "hub" is a bit of a maze and you'll end up going in circles more often than you like. It would've been a simple thing to add more signposts or a mini-map. But the game is so short, this can be overcome in less than 20 minutes with a short guide.

The map can be quite confusing but is broken down in 2 parts:
- The main "Frontier" map (every other level/map is connected to this)
- and the different levels with their respective gates in the main "Frontier" map. These entrance gates

129552558.review:
[h1][b] Keep Calm and Carrion [/b][/h1]

It's very refreshing to play a Metroidvania as the monster for once. Moving the carrion beast is smooth and using it's arsenal of tentacles and parasitic skills enjoyable. The game mechanics are well thought out and provide a puzzle element as gaining and losing body mass enables different abilities.

The minus bits are:
* aiming your tentacles can be fiddly, especially when you have a huge body mass 
* the lack of a map - I know you're a monster and monsters don't use maps - but it's easy to get lost and once you do it takes time to find your way back into the game.
* Game is a bit light in content, 6h to complete which is okay in itself but enemies are only a handful of different types and get repetitive. Also there are secret upgrades which you can only get near the endgame by revisiting older areas. When I unlocked those upgrades... they had become pointless since all enemies in the game were already dead.

Those faults were fairly easy to forgive, as I enjoyed the game throughout. Good graphics, orchestral scary music, fluid controls, in fact the end left me wanting for more.

129549636.review: A delightfully vicious game! Love the concept of reverse horror/being the monster in the dark, and it's executed damn well here — smooth controls of the eldritch horror, reasonable mechanics to traverse the labs, and an environment dripping with aesthetic. Definitely a classic to return to when you're feeling... villainous >:)

How fantastic!
CARRION retroactively makes schlocky monster horror movies brilliant. It shines a light on the tropes of the genre in a way that lets you truly revel in them.

5 stars.

A simple, fun game. It's your basic 'metroidvania' style game, where progress is gated behind upgrades on your path, with simple puzzles and combat(though you could consider the combat as more puzzles). No platforming, as you are too agile to have issues navigating anything that is not sealed by something special. 

There is no map, so you need to pay more attention and not be like the poor reviewer who somehow did not think to posses a man WHO WAS RIGHT THERE and instead kept wandering around the hub and previous levels in confusion for a bit. The game is also not particularly long, though I did not collect all of the extra upgrades hidden in the levels.

The winter DLC was a fun addition, adding a single level but starting with all of the upgrades possible.

I like the game, and I think it was worth the 8 USD I purchased it for.

I loved this game. I do feel the level design and controls could be tweaked, but I don't feel it detracted that much from the experience. The music was awesome. 129341420.review:
So while Carrion isn't a bad game it certainly isn't spectacular either.

As a small game which is a bit of fun where you get to be a cool monster with cool abilities, it's great.

The art style, the general gameplay loop and the vague story are all good and make the game good enough to pick up on a sale.

The bad things make it not worth it to get at full price. The main issue is backtracking without a map. While mostly it's just for 100% there are one or two times where you need to backtrack for the story. The problem is no map, it is really annoying to try and go back to a specific area you know you missed something when you have no idea where it is.

Something I only found out in the last hour or two of the game is that the Hub world and the actual levels are completely separate, there is a point quite early in the game that makes it seem as if getting to the next level requires you to find the entrance to it in a previous level, but that is not the case. This might have been obvious in hindsight but I managed to miss it.

Overall it can be pretty fun but if I had bought the game instead of getting it as a gift I might have liked it quite a bit less.

129011222.review: I of course got this game for the thrill of being the bad guy in the story, but the concept of being a, not brainless, but a weird amorphic bloody organism was so appealing as well--eating the scientists and trying to escape the facility. The "powers" learned are cool and original, helping you navigate the facility, certain tough enemies take some thought as to how to defeat them, but there are multiple ways to do it--it just depends on your personal fighting style. I don't want to give anything away here, just in case you've yet to play, but the ending is...predictable? But to me that didn't matter because I was playing for the creature, not for a ending that would blow my mind. I still was very satisfied with the ending anyway.

128935792.review:
Pros:
- I enjoyed playing as the monster. It was fun to slink around, grab people when they weren't looking, and devour them. 
- Most of the time it was fun to quickly move around the level.
- The game is on the shorter side but it kept my interest throughout. 
- The art and music are great.

Cons:
- I desperately wanted a map. You are rewarded for going back and exploring previous areas but the game world was too difficult to easily navigate without a map. 
- Some of the combat scenarios at the end were janky. Your creature does well quickly moving around the environment but when you're trying to kill a group of enemies you can sometimes grab the wrong thing. I was playing with a controller though so that may have been the issue. 

I really enjoyed the game and I highly recommend it to anyone who is remotely interested!

128731340.review:
[b][u]Very charming visuals[/u][/b]
- The art style coupled with all the destructible objects make for a super fun combo. You rampage around destroying the whole environment around you and showering everything in blood and gibs. The sight of a room after you're done with it is truly something to behold.
[b][u]Fun and intuitive gameplay[/u][/b]
- The game's movement and interactions all happen with the mouse. You have handful of abilities bound to the keyboard and that's about it. You get the hang of the game very quickly and everything does exactly what you want it to. Very simple and very fun.
[b][u]Great level design[/u][/b]
- Getting through zones and environments requires a fair bit of critical thinking. It's by no means a puzzle game but I found that it provided just the right amount of challenge. It makes you feel like you're really outsmarting your prey, which I assume was intended as part of this game's power fantasy.

Can't give this game enough praise. My only issue with it is how short it was. It took me just under 10 hours to explore all zones and get all the steam achievements.

The idea that as your HP goes down your abilities change so you have to adapt your combat techniques is super original and I really loved how that forced me to keep adapting how I progress to suit which "form" I was in due to previous encounters.

The good:
+ Fun gameplay with good balance
+ Some interesting lore and story which presented with pure "Show, don't tell"
+ Gorgeous pixel artstyle
+ Good sound effect/design

The bad: -

The ugly:
* Missing quality of life feature such as map, hint (when you're stuck) and fast travel. Could be annoying for completionist or those with poor sense of direction.

CARRION is very fun Metroidvania game which could be enjoyed by most people. Would recommend this game for those who want satisfying/fun gameplay with some gore/reverse-horror.

128329912.review:
I absolutely adore Carrion, a reverse horror game is such a unique idea and extremely well executed in the form of the gameplay as well. I love the artstyle and the design of the monster, and the abilities it has are absolutely gorey and absurd that I love it.

My only real complaint is that to new players myself included the lack of tips on where to go and no map leads to a lot of aimless wandering and leaving me honestly feeling softlocked at one point. This comes around Leviathan Reef Base to Leviathan Reef Base - Bridge. Just remember there is a guy on a pc in Base that you cannot kill until after HQ and to hit Tab after possession, and do not forget about the exit in Bridge like I did. But all in all great game.

7.6/10

128325313.review: Carrion is a fun little game to play whenever you are tired of being at the mercy of the monsters in horror games. While the game is lacking in content it DID come from a smaller studio and hopefully the next game has the resources to be longer and more content heavy. Now go give those humans whats for!
